chapter.title: 21 Staphylococcus, Micrococcus, and Other Catalase-Positive Cocci

sect1.title: 21 Staphylococcus, Micrococcus, and Other Catalase-Positive Cocci

para.phrase: KARSTEN BECKER, MICHAEL Z. DAVID, AND ROBERT L. SKOV

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Historically, the generaStaphylococcus and Micrococcus were placed together with the genera Stomatococcus and Planococcus in the family Micrococcaceae, containing Gram-positive, catalase-positive cocci (1). However, molecular phylogenetic and chemotaxonomic analyses revealed that staphylococci and micrococci are not closely related but belong to different phyla, the Bacillota (syn. “Firmicutes”) and Actinomycetota (syn. “Actinobacteria”), respectively (2, 3). Now, the genus Staphylococcus is classified as part of the family Staphylococcaceae together with several other genera (Table 1). While in the taxonomic outline of the phylum “Firmicutes” of Bergey’s Manual of Systematics of Archaea and Bacteria (4) the Staphylococcaceae have been placed into the order Bacillales together with Bacillaceae, Planococcaceae, Listeriaceae, and other families, the heterotypic synonym Caryophanales has priority as name of the order (5).

The genusMicrococcus was sustained, but certain micrococcal species previously belonging to this genus were reclassified in the newly established genera Kocuria, Nesterenkonia, Kytococcus, and Dermacoccus. These genera were rearranged into two families, the redefined Micrococcaceae and the newly established Dermacoccaceae, both consisting of Gram-positive cocci with high-G+C-content DNA (6). Recently, the phylum Actinomycetota (syn. “Actinobacteria”) has been again revised and, based on a genome-based taxonomic classification, a further family designated Kytococcaceae has been proposed (7). All three families are assigned to the order Micrococcales (suborder Micrococcineae) of the class Actinobacteria (8). Meanwhile, the family Micrococcaceae comprises an expanding number of genera; however, they are largely without clinical significance (Table 2). The only species of the former genus Stomatococcus, Stomatococcus mucilaginosus, was reclassified as Rothia mucilaginosa. The family Dermacoccaceae contains the type genus Dermacoccus and further genera without medical importance except for members of the Kytococcus genus (Table 2).

An unrelated species of Gram-positive cocci exhibiting a positive catalase reaction and occurring in human specimens isAlloiococcus otitis (of note, often written as “A. otitidis” in literature), the only species of this genus, which is a member of the family Carnobacteriaceae belonging to the order Lactobacillales (class Bacilli).
For further taxonomic details and references, seeBergey’s Manual of Systematics of Archaea and Bacteria (4) and the List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature (https://lpsn.dsmz.de).

sect1.title: Staphylococcaceae
sect1.para: Staphylococci are Gram-positive, nonmotile, non-spore-forming, spherical cells 0.5 to 1.5 μm in diameter, occurring as single cocci, in pairs, as tetrads, or as short chains, which characteristically divide in more than one plane, thereby forming irregular clusters like a bunch of grapes. With the exception of the anaerobic organismsStaphylococcus saccharolyticus (formerly Peptococcus saccharolyticus) and the S. aureus biovar Anaerobius (former Staphylococcus aureus subsp. anaerobius), the staphylococci are facultative anaerobes (Table 3). Staphylococci are usually catalase positive; however, S. saccharolyticus and biovar Anaerobius are catalase negative (Table 4), and catalase-negative strains have rarely been reported for other species. Staphylococcus species are cytochrome oxidase negative in the modified oxidase test; the previous exceptions now belong to the Mammaliicoccus genus (M. fleurettii, M. lentus, M. sciuri, M. stepanovicii, and M. vitulinus) (9). Staphylococci grow in the presence of 10% NaCl between 18°C and 40°C. The metabolism is respiratory and fermentative. The cell wall contains peptidoglycan and teichoic acid. Staphylococci are susceptible to lysostaphin.

The low G+C content of 30 to 39 mol% is a major genotypic criterion of the members of the genusStaphylococcus. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) has been performed for many staphylococcal strains, and completed genome sequences are available for the S. aureus complex and for most other staphylococcal species. The S. aureus genome is composed of a single chromosome ranging in size from approximately 2.8 to 2.9 Mbp (median total length, 2.84 Mbp), with a median G+C content of 32.7 mol%. In comparative genomic analyses, the species’ pangenome (supragenome) was found to comprise 3,221 genes, with 2,245 core genes (10). A wide range of mobile DNA elements have been identified. Most naturally occurring staphylococcal strains contain small multicopy and/or large, conjugative multiresistance plasmids (classes I to III). For more details and other staphylococcal species, see the NCBI Genome database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome).

cTransfer of former members of the genus Micrococcus into the genus Kocuria, i.e., M. varians as K. varians, M. kristinae as K. kristinae, M. roseus as K. rosea, and M. varians as K. varians; reclassification of K. varians CCM 132 as K. carniphila; reclassification of K. erythromyxa, the former Deinococcus erythromyxa (“Sarcina erythromyxa”) as K. rosea.

eFormer member of the family Micrococcaceae.

As of June 2022, 63 species, including 6 subspecies, are recognized in the genusStaphylococcus (for a list of all species and subspecies, see Table 4). Since 1925, staphylococci have been differentiated into coagulase-positive staphylococci and coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) based on the detection of the plasma coagulase (Table 4). For many decades, S. aureus was the only coagulase-positive species. However, additional coagulase-positive (or variable) species, which are mostly animal associated, have been discovered: S. agnetis, S. cornubiensis, S. coagulans (formerly S. schleiferi subsp. coagulans), S. delphini, S. hyicus, S. intermedius, S. lutrae, and S. pseudintermedius. S. intermedius, S. pseudintermedius, and S. delphini form the S. intermedius group (SIG), which has been recently enlarged by a further coagulase-positive species, S. cornubiensis, and by the not yet validly published species “S. ursi,” which in contrast to the other SIG species was found to be coagulase negative.

sect1.para: aSymbols and abbreviations: +, 90% or more species or strains positive; ±, 90% or more species or strains weakly positive; −, 90% or more species or strains negative; V, 11 to 89% of species or strains positive; ND, not determined. Parentheses indicate a delayed reaction.

bGrowth on P agar is under aerobic conditions at 35 to 37°C. Positive growth is indicated for detectable formation of colonies of at least 1 mm in diameter; ± indicates detectable formation of colonies of between 0.5 and 1 mm in diameter. Growth on sheep or bovine blood agar is slightly greater but less discriminative of staphylococci and other genera.

cGrowth is under aerobic conditions at 35 to 37°C for 24 to 48 h. Positive growth is indicated for a number of CFU on selective medium comparable to that on plate count agar and a colony 0.5 mm in diameter; ± indicates a significant reduction in the number of CFU on the selective medium compared to that on plate count agar, and parentheses indicate a colony of pinpoint size to 0.5 mm in diameter.

dSometimes a weak catalase or pseudocatalase reaction can be observed with certain strains of species designated catalase negative. In some species, catalase activity may be activated by hemin supplementation.
eDetects the presence of cytochromes. Some strains of benzidine test-negative species can synthesize cytochromes on aerobic media supplemented with hemin.
fDetermined by the modified oxidase test using tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride-impregnated disks or strips to detect the presence of cytochrome c.
gStandard oxidation-fermentation test.

hA disk is used. + indicates resistance and no zone of inhibition. Micrococcus, Kocuria, Kytococcus, Stomatococcus, and Aerococcus spp. are susceptible and have an inhibition zone 10 to 25 mm in diameter.
iA disk is used. + indicates resistance and no zone of inhibition or a zone up to 9 mm in diameter. Susceptible species have an inhibition zone 15 to 35 mm in diameter.
jSome strains of S. epidermidis adhere tenaciously to the surface of agar, and this property is correlated with heavy slime production.

kS. hominis does not demonstrate growth in the anaerobic portion of a thioglycolate medium within 24 h and may produce only very poor growth in this portion following 3 to 5 days of incubation. However, it grows and ferments glucose anaerobically (standard oxidation-fermentation test). Failure to grow anaerobically in thioglycolate may be due in part to inhibition by the ingredients.

lMacrococcus species can also be differentiated from Staphylococcus species on the basis of their generally larger Gram-stained cell size (≥2 μm) and larger number of chromosome fragments produced by digestion with NotI (12 to 36 fragments).
mA few Micrococcus strains demonstrate high-level (MIC, ≥50 μg/ml) erythromycin resistance.

table.title: TABLE 4 Differentiation of Staphylococcus and Mammaliicoccus species by phenotypic characteristics

sect1.para: aSymbols and abbreviations (unless otherwise indicated): +, 90% or more strains positive; ±, 90% or more strains weakly positive; −, 90% or more strains negative; d, 11 to 89% of strains positive; ND, not determined. Parentheses indicate a delayed reaction. The entries for recently described species are often based on only a few strains.

bPositive is defined as a colony diameter of ≥6 mm after incubation on P agar at 34 to 35°C for 3 days and at room temperature (ca. 25°C) for an additional 2 days; exceptions are S. succinus (4 to 6 mm on tryptic soy agar) and M. fleurettii (8 to 12 mm on tryptic soy agar).

cPositive is defined by the visual detection of carotenoid pigments (e.g., yellow, yellow-orange, or orange) during colony development at normal incubation or room temperatures. Pigments may be enhanced by the addition of milk, fat, glycerol monoacetate, or soaps to P agar.

dGrowth is in a semisolid thioglycolate medium. Symbols: +, moderate or heavy growth down the tube within 18 to 24 h; ±, heavier growth in the upper portion of the tube and weaker growth in the lower, anaerobic portion of tube; −, no visible growth within 48 h but very weak diffuse growth or a few scattered, small colonies may be observed in the lower portion of the tube by 72 to 96 h. Parentheses indicate delayed growth appearing within 24 to 72 h, sometimes noted as large, discrete colonies in the lower portion of the tube.

eGrowth is on P agar or bovine, sheep, or human blood agar at 34 to 37°C. The subspecies of S. equorum and S. succinus grow slowly at 35 to 37°C; the optimum growth temperatures of S. equorum subsp. equorum and S. equorum subsp. linens are 30°C and 32°C, respectively, and those of S. succinus and S. casei are 28°C and 32°C, respectively. Anaerobic species S. saccharolyticus and S. aureus biovar Anaerobius grow very slowly in the presence of air. S. aureus biovar Anaerobius requires the addition of blood, serum, or egg yolk for growth on primary isolation medium. S. auricularis, M. lentus, and M. vitulinus produce just-detectable colonies on P agar in 24 to 36 h, and these colonies remain very small (1 to 2 mm in diameter).

fThe slide agglutination test using rabbit or human plasma detects the expression of clumping factor. Use human plasma for S. lugdunensis and S. schleiferi. Latex agglutination is less reliable for the detection of clumping factor in S. lugdunensis.

gHemolysis on bovine blood agar. Symbols and abbreviations: +, wide zone of hemolysis within 24 to 36 h; (+), delayed moderate to wide zone of hemolysis within 48 to 72 h; (d), no or delayed hemolysis; −, no or only very narrow (1-mm) zone of hemolysis within 72 h. Some strains designated negative may produce a slight greening or browning of blood agar. Analysis of hemolysis for both S. succinus subspecies was performed on Wilkins-Chalgren anaerobe agar plates containing 5% sheep blood.

hCatalase and cytochrome synthesis cannot be induced in S. aureus biovar Anaerobius by the addition of H2O2 or hemin to the culture medium. Catalase activity can be induced in S. saccharolyticus by hemin supplementation. In this species, cytochromes a and b are present in small quantities.
iDetermined by the modified oxidase test to detect the presence of cytochrome c.
jDetermined primarily by commercial rapid identification tests.
kPositive (resistant) is defined by an MIC of ≥1.6 μg/ml or a growth inhibition zone diameter of ≤12 mm (susceptible, ≥16 mm) with a 5-μg novobiocin disk.
lPositive is defined by a growth inhibition zone diameter of <10 mm with a 300-U polymyxin B disk.

mIn 2015, S. argenteus and S. schweitzeri were described as part of the S. aureus-related complex. No biochemical test definitively discriminates between S. aureus and both newly delimited species. S. argenteus colonies are nonpigmented with a creamy white appearance, and S. schweitzeri colonies display a yellowish-pigmented colonial appearance (11). In 2021, S. singaporensis and S. roterodami were established as novel species within the S. aureus-related complex. There is no known biochemical test to delineate S. singaporensis (on the basis of six isolates, which grew as beta-hemolytic, yellow-pigmented colonies) (13). Based on one isolate, S. roterodami grew as gray, beta-hemolytic colonies and was tested β-galactosidase positive (12). The S. aureus biovar Anaerobius is catalase negative (not inducible by H2O2 or hemin to the culture medium) (91).
nTaxonomic changes: S. casei (former Staphylococcus succinus subsp. casei); S. coagulans (former Staphylococcus schleiferi subsp. coagulans) (9).

oApproximately 6 to 15% of strains of S. epidermidis are negative for alkaline phosphatase activity, depending on the population sampled. A low but significant number of clinical isolates are phosphatase negative.
pAll strains tested are also resistant to penicillin G, methicillin, oxacillin, gentamicin, and streptomycin.
qPositive with the STAPH-ZYM tests but negative with the API STAPH tests.
rPositive catalase reaction after growth on hemin-supplemented medium (360).
sDetection of the clumping factor A-encoding gene (clfA) and the thermonuclease-encoding gene (nuc) (361).

tS. ureilyticus represents the former subspecies S. cohnii subsp. urealyticus. An orthographic variant, S. urealyticus, is also found in literature. Unfortunately, the species designation given in the original publication (9) differs between the abstract (S. urealyticus) and its valid species description within the text (S. ureilyticus).
uPositive reactions occur with S. aureus latex agglutination tests that detect clumping factor and/or protein A.

Since 2015, four newly established species have been delimited fromS. aureus: the preferentially nonhuman-primate-adapted S. schweitzeri (former S. aureus sequence type [ST] 2022 [ST2022] and others) and S. argenteus, an early branching lineage comprising the former S. aureus clonal complex (CC) 75 and others (11), followed by the description of S. roterodami and S. singaporensis in 2021 (12, 13). They now encompass the S. aureus-related complex. In this chapter, the term “S. aureus” is used, unless otherwise stated, as prior to these delimitations.

CoNS were later subclassified into novobiocin-susceptible (“S. epidermidis group”) and novobiocin-resistant (“S. saprophyticus group”) species. Historically, the S. epidermidis group comprises, besides the eponym, Staphylococcus capitis, Staphylococcus haemolyticus, Staphylococcus hominis subsp. hominis, Staphylococcus lugdunensis, Staphylococcus saccharolyticus, and Staphylococcus warneri; however, many other species are also novobiocin susceptible (see previous editions of this Manual). In addition to S. saprophyticus, several CoNS species are novobiocin resistant (e.g., Staphylococcus caeli, Staphylococcus cohnii, Staphylococcus kloosii, Staphylococcus pseudoxylosus, and Staphylococcus xylosus). Despite limitations, coagulase activity and novobiocin susceptibility are still used for presumptive identification of clinical isolates.

In 2020, the former members of theStaphylococcus sciuri group were taxonomically reassigned as members of the newly established Mammaliicoccus genus, comprising so far only the previous staphylococcal species Mammaliicoccus sciuri (type species), Mammaliicoccus fleurettii, Mammaliicoccus lentus, Mammaliicoccus stepanovicii, and Mammaliicoccus vitulinus (9). They comprise aerobic to facultative anaerobic species with nonmotile cocci that occur singly or in pairs and irregular clusters. The genome size of mammaliicocci ranges from 2.44 to 2.81 Mbp. Their DNA G+C content ranges from 31.6 to 35.7 mol%.

The genusMacrococcus was established by delimiting the genus Staphylococcus through the description of Macrococcus caseolyticus, the former Staphylococcus (Micrococcus) caseolyticus, and by the description of novel species. For M. caseolyticus, two subspecies, M. caseolyticus subsp. caseolyticus and subsp. hominis, have since been described (14). The macrococcal cells are similar to those of staphylococci, with the exception of their larger cell diameter, reaching 2.5 μm in some species (range, 0.7–2.5 μm in diameter); hence their genus name. Macrococcus is considered to reflect the genome of ancestral bacteria before the speciation of staphylococcal species (15). As shown for the fully sequenced strain JCSC5402, M. caseolyticus has a G+C content of 36.9 mol% (15). In contrast to the cell walls of other macrococci, the cell wall of M. caseolyticus contains teichoic acid. While G+C contents similar to those of staphylococcal species have been shown for Aliicoccus, Corticicoccus, and Nosocomiicoccus, the other genera, Abyssicoccus, Salinicoccus, and Jeotgalicoccus, have a G+C content that is generally higher than those of staphylococci. Whereas salinicocci are strictly aerobes, the other genera comprise facultative anaerobes.

sect1.title: Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae
sect1.para: Most species of the Gram-positive, non-spore-forming familiesMicrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae are characterized by nonmotile and spherical cells that are 0.5 to 1.8 μm in diameter and arranged in tetrads and clusters. Deviating from this, rod-shaped species are found in some genera (e.g., Auritidibacter, Calidifontibacter, and Sinomonas). Arthrobacter, Rothia, and species of other genera may display irregular coccoid forms. Except for R. mucilaginosa, the last two genera are discussed in chapter 28 of this Manual. Members of the Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae have G+C contents in the range of 52 to 75 mol%.

The familyMicrococcaceae includes mostly strictly aerobic and mesophilic species. The type genus, Micrococcus, contains the classical micrococcal species Micrococcus luteus and M. lylae. Other former Micrococcus members are now part of the genus Kocuria, such as Kocuria kristinae, K. varians, and K. rosea (formerly Micrococcus roseus, now united with the former Pelczaria aurantia) (6). The former Micrococcus halobius was transferred into the novel genus Nesterenkonia as Nesterenkonia halobia. For all these genera, several novel species have been described. Two of the former micrococcal species are now assigned to the family Dermacoccaceae, genus Dermacoccus, containing Dermacoccus nishinomiyaensis and other species, or to the family Kytococcaceae, genus Kytococcus, comprising, besides Kytococcus sedentarius, the recently described species K. schroeteri and K. aerolatus.
The key tests for identifying members of theMicrococcaceae and the Dermacoccaceae in clinical specimens are presented in Table 5.

sect1.title: Alloiococcus
sect1.para: The name of the only species of the genusAlloiococcus (family Carnobacteriaceae) still standing in nomenclature is A. otitis [sic] (16); however, the proposed emended name, A. otitidis (17), is frequently used in the literature. This slow-growing species is characterized by Gram-positive ovoid cocci, occurring mostly in clusters and pairs (16). Alloiococci show aerobic atmospheric requirements, but they are able to grow sparsely in a candle jar atmosphere. Their G+C content is 44 to 45 mol%.

sect1.title: Staphylococcus
sect1.para: Most staphylococcal species are part of the resident microbiota of mammals and birds, and their major habitats are the skin and mucous membranes. Staphylococci are opportunistic pathogens, withS. aureus being the most important pathogen in humans and one of the most frequent causes of health care-associated infections, causing substantial morbidity and mortality. S. epidermidis, S. haemolyticus, S. saprophyticus, and S. lugdunensis are also frequent human pathogens, but it should be noted that many other staphylococcal species and subspecies can be encountered in human specimens, such as S. auricularis, S. capitis subsp. capitis, S. capitis subsp. urealyticus, S. caprae, S. cohnii, S. hominis subsp. hominis, S. hominis subsp. novobiosepticus, S. massiliensis, S. pasteuri, S. petrasii, S. pettenkoferi, S. saccharolyticus, S. schleiferi, S. simiae, S. simulans, S. ureilyticus, S. warneri, and S. xylosus.

sect2.title: S. aureus Complex
sect2.para: In humans, the nasal cavity, in particular the posterior vestibules, is the principal habitat forS. aureus (18, 19). Nasal colonization starts with birth and increases rapidly (20, 21). For a general population, an overall prevalence of nasal S. aureus carriage of approximately 40% has been recently determined (22). Depending on the type of participants included in respective studies (e.g., patients, health care workers, remote populations, and healthy volunteers), nasal carriage prevalences ranging from less than 10% to more than 50% have been reported (23). As determined in early longitudinal studies, three types of S. aureus nasal carriers have been historically distinguished: persistent carriers (10 to 35%, carrying one strain over a prolonged period), intermittent carriers (20 to 75%, carrying different strains), and noncarriers (5 to 50%). However, since it was shown that intermittent carriers and noncarriers have similar S. aureus nasal elimination kinetics, it was proposed that there are only two types of nasal carriers: persistent carriers and others (24). From the nares, S. aureus can be transferred to skin and other body areas. The throat, the axillae, the intertriginous skin folds, the perineum, the intestine, and the vagina are also found to be regularly colonized. In a portion of carriers, S. aureus carriage may be detected only in the throat or perineum without concomitant nasal colonization. Studies applying enhanced cultivation procedures, including enrichment broth and/or swabbing of several body sites, in particular the nose, throat, and perineum, have shown that >50% of the participants are colonized by S. aureus (18, 25).

table.title: TABLE 5 Key tests for the identification of Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae found in clinical specimens

row.entry: Different shades of yellow, yellowish green, or cream-white

sect2.para: aSymbols and abbreviations: +, 90% or more strains positive; ±, 90% or more strains weakly positive; −, 90% or more strains negative; d, 11 to 89% of strains positive; ND, not determined. Parentheses indicate a delayed reaction.

Whether health care personnel, patients with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, patients receiving long-term hemodialysis, and people who use intravenous drugs may have higher-than-normalS. aueus nasal carriage rates is a matter of debate, because certain studies do not support earlier findings. Of particular interest, nasal colonization plays a crucial role as a source of invasive infections (26–28).

The population ofS. aureus strains has a highly clonal structure. By multilocus sequence typing (MLST), S. aureus strains can be grouped in sequence types (STs) (currently about 7,800 STs have been described [https://pubmlst.org/organisms/staphylococcus-aureus]) that can be arranged in clonal complexes (CCs) based on founding types, as well as their single- and double-locus variants (SLV/DLV). In the general human population, S. aureus is highly diverse (29). Common S. aureus lineages distributed in health care systems comprise MLST CCs 1, 5, 8, 15, 22, 30, 45, 59, 80, 97, and 121 (30, 31). The livestock-associated (LA) methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) CC398 lineage is frequently observed in some countries and regions with intensive livestock industry (32–35). S. argenteus isolates belong most frequently to CC75. This species and the other novel S. aureus complex members are typeable by MLST; see Table 6 for assigned STs. The S. aureus populations are also divided into four distinct groups based on agr (accessory gene regulator system) allelic variation (36).

Within health care facilities,S. aureus strains are transmitted from patient to patient primarily via hand carriage by medical personnel but also by means of contaminated objects and the environment. Colonized or infected health care personnel may act as reservoirs.

MRSA is of special interest, as it can be considered the oldest worldwide multiresistant pathogen. In settings where MRSA strains are common, distinct antibiotic regimens for empiric therapy ofS. aureus infections are required. MRSA was first encountered in the UK in 1961 (37, 38) and has since then spread worldwide. The global epidemiology of MRSA can be described in waves. A first MRSA wave due to the ST250-SCCmec I clone occurred in the 1960/70s in the United Kingdom, Denmark, and some other European countries as well as in Australia; however, this wave never disseminated worldwide, probably due to a mobilization-defective staphylococcal cassette chromosome (SCCmec) element. A second wave started in the 1980s with the spread of relatively few very successful lineages (in particular, CCs 5, 8, 22, and 45) of health care-associated MRSA (HA-MRSA) harboring SCCmec cassette types II, III, and IV in addition to SCCmec element I. This wave is still ongoing, and these lineages dominated among circulating MRSA strains until the beginning of the 2000s, when community-associated MRSA (CA-MRSA) and, later, livestock-associated MRSA (LA-MRSA) emerged (see below). The prevalence of HA-MRSA varies widely around the world. In some areas of the United States, the MRSA rates temporarily reached >50% of S. aureus isolates (39). In Europe, the population-weighted mean of the MRSA percentage was 15.5% in 2019, including countries such as the Netherlands, Iceland, Estonia, and the Scandinavian countries, where MRSA percentages are very low (<5%), while a series of countries in Western, Middle, and Eastern Europe had medium percentages of <20% and most Mediterranean and Balkan countries exhibited higher percentages (approximately 20 to <50%) (40, 41). In Asia, Australia, and Africa, high MRSA rates (approximately 20 to 80%) have also been noted (42–44). However, in some parts of the world (the United States and most European countries), there are signs of stabilization or even a decrease in the incidence of invasive MRSA infections, e.g., bloodstream infections (40, 41, 45).

The worldwide burden of infections caused by MRSA has further increased due to the introduction of both CA-MRSA (wave 3) and LA-MRSA (wave 4) around the year 2000 (32, 46–52). Both CA-MRSA and LA-MRSA primarily harbor SCCmec elements IV and V. CA-MRSA strains are special because they can survive, spread, and cause infections outside the selective health care environment. However, these strains can also be found in the health care setting and, thus, cause health care-associated infections. The epidemiologic boundaries between CA- and HA-MRSA strains have become blurred (53). CA-MRSA isolates were first observed among Australian Indigenous peoples in the late 1980s but were not encountered globally until the late 1990s when diverse CA-MRSA lineages appeared in different parts of the world. In the United States, the pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) type USA400 (ST1-IV) and, later, type USA300 (ST8-IV; usually spa type t008) are the most prevalent clones (54–58). For other parts of the world, an array of diverse CA-MRSA clones has been reported, such as ST80-IV (spa type t044) in Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East; ST30-IV (“Southwest Pacific clone”) in Australia and Asia; ST59-V and ST772 (“Bengal Bay clone”) in Asia; ST88 and ST1797 in Africa; and ST93-IV in Australia (33, 42, 43, 59–61). While the different CA-MRSA clones were initially geographically segregated, the strains have become more widespread worldwide, particularly USA300 (20, 33, 61–63). Recent studies using WGS have delineated the successful spread of USA300 and ST80-IV as a function of human migration and progressively increasing uptake of resistance (mecA) and virulence factors such as Panton-Valentine leukocidin (PVL) and arginine catabolic mobile element (ACME) (64–66).

CA-MRSA strains are more likely to carry PVL, a pore-forming toxin with potent cytolytic and inflammatory activities (67, 68). Of note, PVL possession is not restricted to CA-MRSA. Isolates of many pandemic methicillin-susceptible S. aureus (MSSA) lineages may carry the PVL genes. Particularly in African populations, a high prevalence of PVL-positive MSSA has been reported (42, 69–71). Populations at increased risk for USA300 colonization and/or infections include children in day care centers, athletes, military recruits, jail inmates, and men who have sex with men; however, colonization and infection outside the initially recognized, high-risk, specific population groups are increasingly being documented (72, 73). Colonization of healthy individuals with CA-MRSA differs widely in terms of risk factors, region, and age (74, 75). CA-MRSA causes superficial skin and soft tissue infections and can rarely be associated with necrotizing fasciitis and myositis, necrotizing pneumonia, and other severe infections (73, 76). Necrotizing pneumonia by PVL-positive MRSA and MSSA in young, otherwise healthy children following a respiratory viral infection (most frequently influenza) can be a devastating disease (67). However, some of the distinctions between HA-MRSA and CA-MRSA strains may disappear, since CA-MRSA is now becoming endemic in hospitals and acquiring additional resistance phenotypes (77, 78).

Until recently, direct or indirect human-to-human transmission has been the primary route for the transmission of both MSSA and MRSA strains, but now animals have become a significant additional reservoir. For companion animals, MRSA infection is primarily a humanosis (i.e., humans infect the animals, which then can transmit the organism back) (79). This is in contrast to the situation with the emerging LA-MRSA lineages, such as CC398, for which livestock represent a genuine zoonotic risk to humans (80–82). LA-MRSA is especially prevalent in Europe and Asia but has been documented from all five continents (35, 83, 84). Pigs appear to be the main reservoir, but LA-MRSA has been documented in a large range of animals, including chickens, veal calves, cows, sheep, and horses (47, 85). Most European LA-MRSA strains belong to CC398, as defined by MLST, with t011 and t034 as the most frequent spa types (86). In contrast, ST9 is the predominant LA-MRSA clonal lineage in many Asian countries (87). In the Americas, where the prevalence seems somewhat lower, ST398 and ST5 have been reported (82). LA-MRSA strains typically lack PVL as well as the genes of the immune evasion cluster. In general, LA-MRSA CC398 isolates can cause all types of infections attributed to S. aureus, including some that are fatal (81). The observed dominance of less serious infections may be due to the fact that the majority of the CC398 carriers comprise healthy younger individuals with intact immune defense (“healthy worker effect”) (88). Almost all LA-MRSA CC398 isolates exhibit resistance to tetracyclines, a very frequently used antibiotic in veterinary medicine, but may also exhibit resistance to other antibiotic classes. However, LA-MRSA isolates exhibit multiresistant traits to a lesser extent than HA-MRSA isolates (47). With the exception of farm workers, MRSA carriage in the general populations is still low, even in areas with high percentages of LA-MRSA in livestock (22, 89).

S. aureus is commonly known to colonize many domestic and wild animal species harboring diverse lineages (90). The S. aureus biovar Anaerobius has been recovered from subcutaneous abscesses of sheep (91). So far, this subspecies has not been isolated from human clinical specimens.

S. argenteus, which was delineated from S. aureus in 2015 (11), is globally distributed and is found in both humans and animals. In humans, the reported prevalence of S. argenteus varies greatly, with at least three hot spots (Australian Indigenous people, Southeast Asia, and remote human populations in the Amazon). In Australian Indigenous communities, S. argenteus has been shown to account for up to 71% of CA-MRSA (92), whereas in Europe it seems to be below 1% of coagulase-positive staphylococci (93). The true prevalence of S. argenteus is, however, difficult to estimate, as only few laboratories investigate routinely for S. argenteus (94). S. argenteus causes a similar spectrum of disease as do S. aureus; however, it is still uncertain whether its pathogenic potential and transmissibility are similar to those of S. aureus (94). S. schweitzeri, another delineated species (11), has so far only been found in sub-Saharan Africa and primarily in animals (fruit bats and nonhuman primates) (95). The two additional novel species of the S. aureus-related complex described in 2021 have been isolated from human specimens and designated S. roterodami and S. singaporensis (12, 13). The only S. roterodami isolate reported to date was isolated from an acute foot wound (12), and the six S. singaporensis isolates were recovered mainly from skin and soft tissue infection specimens (13).

sect2.title: Non-S. aureus Complex Coagulase-Positive Species
sect2.para: S. intermedius, S. pseudintermedius (delineated in 2005) (96), S. delphini, and S. cornubiensis are closely related coagulase-positive species comprising the S. intermedius group (SIG) together with “S. ursi,” but this last proposed species is coagulase negative. S. intermedius, S. pseudintermedius, and S. delphini are commonly recovered from birds, carnivores, and other mammals (e.g., horses and cats). The recently discovered species S. cornubiensis was isolated from a human skin infection (97). Since it is very difficult to differentiate among these species, it is very likely that previously reported S. intermedius isolates with variant biotypes might have included S. delphini and, in particular, S. pseudintermedius. S. pseudintermedius is the predominant coagulase-positive Staphylococcus species recovered from normal and infected canine skin (96). Further coagulase-positive animal-adapted staphylococci are S. coagulans, S. felis, and S. lutrae. S. hyicus is known as the cause of porcine exudative epidermitis in pigs, but also causes disease in poultry, cattle, and horses. S. agnetis has been reported from bovine milk. S. hyicus and S. agnetis are coagulase variable. In the case of close contacts between animals (pets or livestock) and their owners, colonization of these animals by, e.g., extended-host-spectrum genotypes of S. aureus may occur (98).

sect2.title: Coagulase-Negative Staphylococci
sect2.para: CoNS are part of the core microbiota of the skin and mucous membranes of animals and humans (99). In humans, S. epidermidis is the most frequently recovered staphylococcal species colonizing the body surface, where it is particularly prevalent on moist areas, such as the axillae, inguinal and perineal areas, anterior nares, and toe webs. Other staphylococcal species may have more localized primary niches; e.g., S. auricularis is part of the healthy human external auditory canal microbiota, exclusively colonizing this region; S. capitis is found surrounding the sebaceous glands on the forehead and scalp following puberty; S. haemolyticus and S. hominis are preferentially isolated from axillae and pubic areas high in apocrine glands; and S. saprophyticus frequently colonizes the rectum and the genitourinary tracts of young women. S. lugdunensis is frequently found on the lower extremities and the groin. However, these species may be found occasionally on other body sites. Some more recently described staphylococcal species, such as S. massiliensis, S. pettenkoferi, and S. petrasii, are also likely to be part of the human skin microbiota (100–102).

S. xylosus is a common commensal of the skin and the mucous membranes of many animals and, occasionally, of humans. S. xylosus represents one of the major starter cultures used for meat fermentation. S. kloosii, S. equorum subsp. equorum, and S. gallinarum are found on several mammals and food products. S. chromogenes is a common resident of cloven-hoofed animals and, in addition, may be isolated from their food products. S. arlettae is found on mammals and birds. S. nepalensis has been isolated from Himalayan goats. S. muscae has been found on flies. S. rostri was isolated from the noses of pigs, S. devriesei from bovine udders, and S. microti from free-living common voles. S. carnosus, S. condimenti, S. devriesei, S. equorum subsp. linens, S. piscifermentans, and S. casei have been associated with fermented food and dairy products. S. argensis was isolated from river sediments, and S. succinus was isolated from an amber fragment. However, the complete and/or true natural habitat for many of these species is still unclear.

sect2.title: Mammaliicoccus
sect2.para: M. sciuri is known as a commensal of the skin and the mucous membranes of many animals and, occasionally, of humans. Isolates of this species have been also found in food. M. vitulinus (synonym, Staphylococcus pulvereri) is found preferentially on horses and whales. M. lentus is associated with cloven-hoofed animals and can be isolated from their food products. M. fleurettii has been recovered from fermented food and dairy products. The skin and the intestinal tract of wild small mammals such as rodents and insectivores are the source for M. stepanovicii isolates.

sect1.title: Abyssicoccus, Aliicoccus, Corticicoccus, Jeotgalicoccus, Macrococcus, Nosocomiicoccus, and Salinicoccus
sect1.para: The genusMacrococcus comprises eight mostly hoofed-animal-adapted species, including M. caseolyticus, first described as Staphylococcus caseolyticus (103). This species is found on food such as sausages and meat products. Recently, several macrococcal species (M. bohemicus, M. caseolyticus, M. goetzii, and M. epidermidis) have been recovered also from human specimens (14). M. canis has been recently discovered from skin specimens from dogs (71).

Thus far, the only reported recovery ofNosocomiicoccus massiliensis has been from a fecal sample of an HIV-infected patient (72). Nosocomiicoccus ampullae was first isolated from surfaces of bottles of saline solution used in wound cleansing (73). Later reports of this species include isolation from a human urine sample and 16S rRNA gene-based detection in a fermented soybean condiment.

The halotolerant/halophilicAbyssicoccus, Aliicoccus, Jeotgalicoccus, and Salinicoccus species are recovered from fermented seafood and salted fish or found in saline and desert soil, marine sediments, hypersaline lakes, or salt mines. Corticicoccus has been identified from bark tissue canker of a poplar.

sect1.title: Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae
sect1.para: The skin of humans and other mammals is the primary habitat for mostMicrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae recovered from clinical specimens. Cutaneous populations of micrococci are carried by most people (ca. 96%), with M. luteus being the most frequent species, followed by K. varians. R. mucilaginosa is probably a normal inhabitant of the mouth and upper respiratory tract (104). Animal and dairy products may be considered secondary sources of micrococci. Many of the recently discovered members of the Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae are associated with different environmental habitats.

sect1.title: Alloiococcus
sect1.para: A. otitis is detected in the outer ear canals of healthy persons at a high prevalence, suggesting that alloiococci are part of the normal bacterial microbiota (105). By analyzing the microbiome of the middle ear based on amplicon sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene, alloicocci were found in high abundance in the external auditory canal, and they were recognized as competing with staphylococci (106, 107).

sect1.title: Staphylococcus and Other Staphylococcaceae
sect1.para: Many staphylococcal species are classical opportunists colonizing skin and mucous membranes but may become pathogenic in a species- and strain-dependent manner following breaks in the cutaneous epithelial barrier through trauma or medical interventions. The recovery of a staphylococcal isolate always requires assessment of clinical significance to determine whether it is a contaminant, colonizer, or pathogen.

S. aureus is the clinically most important species, as it is capable of causing a wide range of human and animal diseases (108). S. aureus possesses an extensive arsenal of often redundant and overlapping virulence factors, such as adhesins, enzymes, and toxins, and has various strategies to evade the host immune response. In addition, while many antistaphylococcal drugs have been introduced, strains of this pathogen have developed resistance to each of the therapeutic agents available. U.S. National Healthcare Safety Network data indicate that S. aureus is the second leading cause of health care-associated infections after Escherichia coli and, in particular, the most common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia, surgical site infection, and both adult central line-associated and hemodialysis-related bloodstream infection (109, 110).

Disease entities caused byS. aureus can be broadly divided into toxin-mediated diseases and suppurative infections, comprising skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs), infections of sterile sites and internal organs, systemic infections, and foreign-body-related infections (FBRIs). SSTIs are the most frequent infections in community-associated S. aureus infections, including those caused by CA-MRSA strains. The spectrum of SSTIs ranges from superficial (impetigo, folliculitis, furuncles/carbuncles, pyoderma, and wound infections) to deep infections (abscesses, mastitis, cellulitis, and pyomyositis) to acute life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis and myositis. Infection of deep sites may involve any body compartment and organ system, resulting in empyema, osteomyelitis, arthritis, endocarditis, pneumonia, otitis media, sinusitis, mastoiditis, endophthalmitis, and parotitis. Any localized S. aureus infection can become invasive and lead to bacteremia. Systemic infections comprise primary and secondary bacteremia, meningitis, and endocarditis. Bacteremia may be complicated by endocarditis, septic emboli (e.g., pulmonary or cerebral emboli), and metastatic foci (e.g., renal abscrss or vertebral osteomyelitis). Congenital or acquired defects in host defense and the presence of foreign bodies may predispose patients to disseminated or invasive infections.

Besides an acute, aggressive course of infection,S. aureus may cause chronic, persistent, and relapsing infections, often due to a phenotypic subpopulation designated small-colony variants (SCVs), which present adapted phenotypes for intracellular persistence (111). Switching between the normal and the SCV phenotype seems to be a highly dynamic process in both directions for adaptation to intra- and extracellular conditions (112–114), respectively; this phenotype switching also challenges accurate detection in routine laboratory practice (see below). SCVs of S. aureus and other staphylococcal species (e.g., S. epidermidis and S. lugdunensis) have been isolated from patients with chronic osteomyelitis, abscesses, and FBRIs as well as from cystic fibrosis patients with chronic airway infection (115).

Classical toxin-mediated diseases due toS. aureus comprise staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS), staphylococcal food poisoning, and bullous impetigo, including its generalized form, the staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). TSS is associated with colonization by or infection with an isolate of S. aureus that is positive for TSS toxin 1 (TSST-1) or, less frequently, for other members of the staphylococcal pyrogenic toxin superantigen (PTSAg) family (primarily staphylococcal enterotoxin B or C). TSS is diagnosed on clinical grounds and is characterized by high fever, rapid-onset hypotension, a diffuse erythematous rash (“sunburn-like”) that desquamates 1 to 2 weeks after onset, often affecting the palms and soles, and involvement of three or more organ systems. After its initial description in children, TSS was associated with menstruating women using highly absorbent tampons (116). While the incidence of menstrual TSS decreased due to changes in the absorbency of tampons and their chemical composition, the frequency of nonmenstrual TSS cases has remained constant since the 1980s (117). Although often no source of infection is confirmed, nonmenstrual TSS is usually associated with a postoperative wound or soft tissue infection that may be mild.

Staphylococcal food poisoning, caused by consumption of food contaminated with one or more preformed, relatively heat-stable enterotoxins (commonly SEA or SEB), results in about 241,000 cases of foodborne illness each year in the U.S. (118). Nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea occur 2 to 6 h after food ingestion. Although symptoms can be quite severe, they usually subside 8 to 12 h later.

Bullous impetigo and SSSS are caused by exfoliative (epidermolytic) toxins A (ETA) and B (ETB). SSSS is most often diagnosed in neonates and young children (82). In addition to severe exfoliation affecting up to 90% or more of the entire body surface (Ritter’s disease), a localized form (pemphigus neonatorum) with a few blisters also occurs. Diagnosis is made based on clinical features, including Nikolsky’s sign, in which the skin wrinkles on gentle pressure and peels away, demonstrating separation of the layers of the skin due to exfoliation.

Compared toS. aureus, reduced virulence was assumed in early reports for the sister species S. argenteus due to lack of the carotenoid pigment staphyloxanthin (119). However, S. argenteus has comparable rates of morbidity and of skin and soft tissue infections as well as invasive infections, including bone and joint infections, pneumonia, and bacteremia (94, 120–122). Transmission of S. schweitzeri, another sister species within the S. aureus complex, from African tropical wildlife (primates, bats, and fomites) to humans may occur only very rarely; few isolates have been recovered from the nasopharynx of colonized humans, and no human infections have been reported to date (94, 123, 124). However, S. schweitzeri isolates display virulence phenotypes comparable to S. aureus in in vitro assays (125). For the few cases of the most recently described members of the S. aureus complex, S. singaporensis and S. roterodami, clinical infection features resemble those of S. aureus (12, 13). However, clinical and pathogenetic studies are lacking.

The other non-S. aureus coagulase-positive or -variable staphylococci are members of the skin microbiotas of various animal species and occasionally cause infections in their hosts as well as in humans in contact with the animals. The members of the S. intermedius-S. pseudintermedius-S. delphini cluster are the most common etiologic agents of canine pyoderma and external otitis. Infections caused by methicillin-resistant strains of S. pseudintermedius have increased in incidence as a cause of these syndromes since the mid-2000s (126). S. hyicus is predominantly associated with exudative epidermitis (greasy pig syndrome) in pigs, S. coagulans (former S. schleiferi subsp. coagulans) is found in dogs suffering from external otitis, and S. aureus biovar Anaerobius is the etiological agent of abscess disease, a specific lymphadenitis of sheep and goats. In humans, S. intermedius-S. pseudintermedius is occasionally responsible for canine-inflicted wound infections, FBRIs, food poisoning, and invasive infections in immunocompromised patients. Only a few human infections due to S. schleiferi, S. coagulans, and S. hyicus have been documented, including rare cases of bacteremia (127–129). S. agnetis isolates have been recovered from bovine intramammary infections as well as costochondritis and invasive infections in chickens (94, 130, 131).

Since the 1980s, CoNS have been increasingly recognized as health care-associated pathogens, especiallyS. epidermidis and S. haemolyticus (99, 132, 133). Both species are often referred to as “medium-pathogenicity” staphylococci, as they cause health care-associated infections mainly in patients with predisposing factors, such as immunodeficiency and/or the presence of indwelling or implanted foreign polymer bodies (134, 135). Also, S. lugdunensis and S. saprophyticus may be categorized in this group (described separately). CoNS are less often implicated as the cause of infections of natural tissue. Overall, the clinical appearance of infections caused by CoNS is associated with subacute or chronic clinical courses without fulminant signs, and they are seldom life-threatening. CoNS are the most common microorganism group recovered from positive blood cultures, but fewer than 10% are clinically significant in adults (99). Virtually any surgically inserted materials and devices may become infected by CoNS (99, 136). CoNS that cause health care-associated bloodstream infections are typically associated with central and peripheral intravascular catheters (137). Most important in the pathogenesis of FBRIs is the ability of CoNS to colonize the surface of a device by the formation of a thick, multilayered biofilm (138). S. epidermidis is the predominant cause of infections associated with prosthetic vascular grafts, prosthetic orthopedic devices, and cerebrospinal fluid shunts. CoNS are frequently isolated as causative agents of prosthetic-valve endocarditis; rarely (about 5% of cases), they are involved in infections of (previously damaged) native valves (139). Right-sided native-valve endocarditis is primarily observed in intravenous-drug abusers. Premature neonates are predisposed to invasive infections due to CoNS. CoNS are the most common organisms identified in early- and late-onset bloodstream infections in this patient group (140, 141).

Of all CoNS,S. lugdunensis holds a special position because its infections generally resemble those caused by S. aureus rather than those caused by other CoNS (99, 142). In recent years, this species has been recognized as a relatively frequent cause of skin abscesses and wound infections, in particular below the waist, and attention should be given to this in the laboratory (143). Nevertheless, S. lugdunensis is especially renowned for causing unusually fulminant cases of native-valve endocarditis in addition to prosthetic-valve endocarditis (144). Thus, patients with S. lugdunensis bacteremia should be carefully examined for signs of endocarditis (145). In addition to causing other invasive infections, this organism is a common pathogen involved in FBRIs.

Based on special urotropic and ecologic characteristics,S. saprophyticus is a well-documented causative agent of acute, commonly recurrent urinary tract infections in young, otherwise healthy, sexually active women and, less frequently, in young men or boys. This pathogen is the second most common (after Escherichia coli) cause of uncomplicated cystitis among young women (146). While colony counts of ≥100,000 CFU/ml in two or more cultures of midstream urine usually indicate significant bacteriuria, lower counts may be significant in the symptomatic patient. Infections due to the temporarily established, cattle-associated subspecies S. saprophyticus subsp. bovis have not been reported.

For various other CoNS species (e.g.,S. capitis, S. chromogenes, S. cohnii, S. condimenti, S. hominis, S. pasteuri, S. pettenkoferi, S. warneri, and S. xylosus), case reports and series predominantly reporting on FBRIs have been published (101, 147–153). Moreover, certain clonal lineages may be associated with infections in distinct populations as recently shown for the multidrug-resistant S. capitis clone NRCS-A, which emerged as a major pathogen among newborns in neonatal intensive care units (154, 155). In contrast, S. carnosus, S. piscifermentans, S. equorum subsp. linens, and other staphylococcal species involved mainly in food production have been regarded as nonpathogenic staphylococci. Of note, routinely applied identification procedures may fail in the identification of rarely encountered and/or animal-associated staphylococcal species; thus, reports on these species can be misleading.

TheMammaliicoccus species have no clinical significance for human medicine in the majority with the exception of M. sciuri and M. lentus, for which human infections (e.g., endocarditis, peritonitis, and FBRIs) have occasionally been described (156, 157).

Since human infections due toAbyssicoccus, Aliicoccus, Corticicoccus, Jeotgalicoccus, Macrococcus, Nosocomiicoccus, and Salinicoccus have not been described, these genera are not discussed further in this chapter.

sect1.title: Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae
sect1.para: While micrococci are generally acknowledged as harmless saprophytes, they can also act as opportunistic pathogens.Dermacoccus, Micrococcus, Kocuria, and Kytococcus species have been found to cause infections such as endocarditis, meningitis, pneumonia, and sepsis or FBRIs predominantly in immunocompromised patients (158–164). However, recovery of the more recently described environmental species of the Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae should be assessed for clinical significance, as reported for Kocuria rhizophila, Kocuria marina, and Dermacoccus barathri (165–167). Auritidibacter ignavus has been cultivated from the ear swab of a patient with otitis externa; however, its role as a causative agent has not been clarified (168).

R. mucilaginosa has been implicated in cases of bacteremia, endocarditis, endophthalmitis, intravascular catheter-related and central nervous system infections, pneumonia, peritonitis, septicemia, and cervical necrotizing fasciitis (169–172).
Since human infections due to the other genera of theMicrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae families have not been reported, they are not discussed further in this chapter.

sect1.title: Alloiococcus
sect1.para: A. otitis has been associated with infections of the middle ear; however, its role in the pathogenesis of otitis media remains a matter of debate (173–175). Some case reports have described other entities, such as endocarditis and endophthalmitis, some of which followed chronic otitis media (176).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: The general principles of collection, transport, and storage of specimens given inchapter 19 of this Manual are applicable to the microorganisms listed in this chapter. No special methods or precautions are usually required for these organisms, because they are easily obtained from clinical material of most infection sites and are relatively resistant to drying and to moderate temperature changes. While some staphylococcal species may require anaerobic conditions or CO2 supplementation for satisfactory growth, they survive transport and limited storage in air.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Direct microscopic examination of normally sterile fluids, such as cerebrospinal fluid and joint aspirates, may be helpful. For nonsterile fluids, microscopy may also be useful; however, the presence of inflammatory cells versus epithelial cells has to be taken into consideration.

Microorganisms discussed here are Gram-positive, nonmotile, non-spore-forming cocci that are arranged mostly in pairs and tetrads but may also occur singly, in irregular (grape-like) clusters, or in short chains (three or four cells). However, within theMicrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae, some species exhibit rod-shaped cells and have been shown to be motile. Positive findings of direct microscopic examination should be reported as “Gram-positive cocci resembling staphylococci” or, alternatively, as “Gram-positive cocci in clusters.”

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Particularly for MRSA screening from surveillance swabs, but increasingly also for clinical samples, direct amplification-based approaches have been introduced. Two principal approaches have been developed: (i) the multiple-locus approach, which detects the methicillin resistance-encoding genesmecA and mecC and additionally an S. aureus-specific target (see “Species Identification by Nucleic Acid-Based Approaches” below) and (ii) the single-locus approach targeting the 3′ extremity of the SCCmec and the neighboring 5′ orfX region of the S. aureus chromosome. The latter approach amplifies both a resistance marker and a species-specific marker with one pair of primers (177).

The multiple-locus approach may be influenced by the presence of both MSSA and methicillin-resistant CoNS (MR-CoNS) in a sample and thus may lead to false-positive MRSA findings (178). Nevertheless, the fundamental advantage of this approach is the direct detection of the methicillin resistance-encoding genes, mecA and, if additionally targeted, its homolog, mecC. Tests applying this principle are commercially available, and newer generations of all these assays include also the detection of mecC (179, 180). Some of these assays combine this multiple-locus approach with a single-locus amplification strategy (see below).

The single-locus approach overcomes the drawbacks caused by MSSA/MR-CoNS coexistence in screening specimens (177). This principle is the basis for several rapid test systems. However, the use of the SCCmec region as a surrogate marker instead of direct detection of mecA may lead to false-negative results due to the high variability of the SCCmec primer binding sites, a situation that is particularly problematic in the case of rare or still-unknown SCCmec (sub)types. In addition, false-positive results may occur due to the replacement of the mecA gene within the cassette by other genes (e.g., resistance or capsule-encoding genes) and, particularly, by partial excision of the cassette, leading to remnants that lack the mec gene complex but still contain the primer binding sites on the 3′ end of the SCC cassette (“dropout” isolates) (181).

A recently published in-house assay, based on a long-range PCR targeting theorfX region and the mecA gene and introducing biotin labeling for magnetic beads capturing tail sequences as templates for subsequent second-round detection PCRs, claims to overcome the false-negative and false-positive drawbacks of single- and multiple-locus approaches (182). Whether the general amplification efficiency problems of long-range PCRs influence the robustness of this assay for clinical use requires further evaluation.

Of note, most of these amplification-based rapid MRSA screening assays were not primarily designed to identify MRSA or MSSA infections. The performance of the single-locus approach may be influenced by local epidemiology, but overall, these assays are characterized by very high negative predictive values (approximately 97 to 99%) but are hampered by moderate positive predictive values (approximately 65 to 95%). To date, MRSA cultures remain essential for confirming molecular results, for typing purposes, and for determination of the complete susceptibility profile.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: As staphylococci and micrococci are part of the microbiota of the skin and mucous membranes, careful procedures should be used to isolate organisms from the presumed focus of infection without collecting surrounding microbiota. The basic procedures for culture and isolation described inchapters 19 and 20 of this Manual should be followed. In this section, in particular, some special aspects of MRSA cultivation are discussed.

The primary culture plate used for the isolation of staphylococci from clinical specimens is Columbia or tryptic soy blood agar containing 5% defibrinated sheep (or horse) blood (see alsochapter 20). An abundant growth of most staphylococcal species occurs within 18 to 24 h. The simultaneous use of an enrichment broth (i.e., dextrose broth) streaked after 24 and 48 h on Columbia blood agar may enhance the recovery rate of S. aureus and other staphylococci.

The use of selective agars forS. aureus, such as mannitol salt agar, egg yolk-tellurite pyruvate-containing Baird-Parker medium, Columbia colistin-nalidixic acid agar, lipase-salt-mannitol agar, phenylethyl alcohol agar, and selective agars using chromogenic enzyme substrates specifically for S. aureus, may be appropriate for specimens from heavily contaminated sources, such as feces and respiratory cultures from patients with cystic fibrosis. It is mandatory to confirm putative S. aureus isolates recovered on these media.

Various selective agars using chromogenic enzyme substrates specifically forS. aureus are commercially available with chromogen-dependent coloration of the colonies. In particular, for screening purposes, the chromogenic agars have been proven to be suitably sensitive and specific, allowing a presumptive but not final identification.

The diagnosis of catheter-related bloodstream infections by CoNS and other organisms remains a major challenge. One of the most frequently studied diagnostic techniques is the semiquantitative roll-plate catheter culture method. With this technique, the distal segment of the central venous catheter is cut and rolled across the surface of a Columbia blood agar plate at least four times, followed by overnight incubation. Colony counts of 15 CFU or more may indicate catheter colonization. Some reports claim a higher sensitivity with a quantitative sonication technique for detection of both intraluminal and extraluminal bacteria (183). However, several studies failed to show superiority of the sonication approach to the semiquantitative roll-plate catheter culture technique (184). Examination of paired quantitative blood cultures drawn simultaneously from the catheter and a peripheral vein, enhanced by the analysis of differential time to positivity, represents an example of an approach that does not require immediate catheter removal (see also “Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results” below).

Micrococci andR. mucilaginosa should be cultivated as described for staphylococci on Columbia blood agar at 35 to 37°C under aerobic conditions. However, to obtain abundant growth of Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae, incubation times of 36 to 48 h are needed.
Because of its low growth rate, it is difficult to isolateA. otitis by conventional nonselective culture methods. Blood agar plates with 6% NaCl improve recovery.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: The basic criteria for distinguishing among catalase-positive Gram-positive cocci and their relatives as well as other microbial taxa are given in “Description of the Families” above and inTable 3. Within the past few years, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has to a large extent replaced biochemical identification procedures (see detailed information in previous editions of this Manual) and has become the routine approach in many clinical microbiology laboratories for rapid and specific identification of staphylococci and other catalase-positive cocci. Nucleic acid-based molecular methods targeting species-specific sequences or DNA sequencing-based approaches can augment ambiguous identification results.

sect1.title: Staphylococcus and Related Genera
sect1.para: The application of the extensive scheme of biochemical and other physiological key characteristics of staphylococcal species originally published by Kloos and Schleifer in 1975 (185) has been replaced by the use of commercial identification systems and recently by MALDI-TOF MS.

sect2.title: Colony Morphology
sect2.para: Most staphylococcal colonies are 1 to 3 mm in diameter within 24 h and 3 to 8 mm in diameter after 72 h of incubation in air at 34 to 37°C. Exceptions are those ofS. aureus biovar Anaerobius, S. saccharolyticus, S. auricularis, S. equorum, M. vitulinus, and M. lentus, which grow more slowly and usually require 24 to 36 h for detectable colony development. Further incubation of agar plates for a period of up to 48 to 72 h (optimally followed by 2-day incubation at room temperature) enhances morphologic differences.

On routine blood agar, the typicalS. aureus colony is pigmented (gray or gray-white with a yellowish tint through yellow to orange), smooth, entire, slightly raised, and hemolytic (Fig. 1). Mucoid colonies due to highly encapsulated strains are rarely encountered. Some isolates of S. aureus as well as some CoNS species (e.g., S. haemolyticus and S. lugdunensis) may have a hazy or distinct zone of beta-hemolysis around the colonies, ranging from weak to strong. SCVs of S. aureus or other staphylococcal species are characterized by pinpoint colonies (1/10 the size of the wild type), mostly nonpigmented and nonhemolytic after 24 to 72 h of incubation (Fig. 1) (111, 115). SCVs are often mixed with colonies displaying the normal phenotype, thus giving the appearance of a mixed culture. Upon subculture, they may remain stable or revert to the wild type. Depending on their auxotrophy, normal growth may be restored if the isolate is grown in the presence of hemin, menadione, or thymidine and/or CO2 supplementation (111).

The typical colony appearance of most CoNS species is nonpigmented, smooth, entire, glistening, and opaque. Rare strong slime producers display mucoid colony morphology. Colony diameters reach 3 to 6 mm after 3 days of incubation. Colonies ofS. chromogenes, S. devriesei, S. lugdunensis, S. warneri, and S. xylosus are found to be more or less regularly gray to yellow, yellow, or yellow to orange (99). Other CoNS species may show pigmentation that is usually yellowish.

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Columbia blood agar plate with 5% sheep blood showing S. aureus subsp. aureus after 24 h of incubation. The normal phenotype is grayish colonies with a yellowish tint surrounded by a hemolysis zone (arrows), and the small-colony phenotype is characterized by tiny, nonhemolytic, and nonpigmented colonies (dashed arrows).

sect2.para: Colonies ofMammaliicoccus are circular, smooth, glistening, and opaque. M. sciuri colonies are large and mostly gray-white (often with a yellowish or cream-colored tint toward the often elevated center) or yellowish or gray-yellow (186). M. vitulinus (formerly S. pulvereri) exhibit nonpigmented or white colonies with yellowish tint (187). M. lentus forms white, gray-white, or creamy colonies (188). Colonies of M. stepanovicii and M. fleurettii are nonpigmented; those of the latter species are sometimes creamy (189, 190).

sect2.title: Coagulase Production and Clumping Factor Detection
sect2.para: A widely used criterion for the identification ofS. aureus in the clinical laboratory is the clotting of plasma proven by two different tests: (i) detection of the extracellular free coagulase (staphylocoagulase) by the tube test due to staphylococcal coagulase, which converts fibrinogen to fibrin, and (ii) detection of the so-called “cell wall-bound coagulase” (i.e., the clumping factor) as part of slide agglutination tests. Both approaches may still be helpful in the case of ambiguous results by MALDI-TOF MS or in settings where MALDI-TOF MS is not available.

The tube coagulase test is performed by transferring colony material into rabbit plasma. It is crucial to incubate the tube at 37°C for 4 h. Any degree of clotting represents a positive test. A flocculent or fibrous precipitate is not a true clot and should be recorded as negative. If no clot is formed by 4 h, the tube should be read again after 18 h of incubation at 37°C. False-negative results may occur for some strains producing staphylokinase, which may lyse the clot after formation, and if SCVs are tested. The detection of free coagulase in staphylococci obtained from human specimens is usually equated with the species identification ofS. aureus. However, in veterinary microbiological laboratories and for human specimens from animal-inflicted wounds, the non-S. aureus coagulase-positive or -variable species should be considered (Table 4).

To overcome the low sensitivity and specificity of the classical slide agglutination test and of the long incubation time of the tube coagulase test, rapid latex and hemagglutination assays allowing presumptive identification ofS. aureus have been developed. Third-generation assays include detection of protein A, clumping factor A, and capsular polysaccharide serotypes 5 and 8. They exhibit a high sensitivity (>98 to 100%) but a relatively low specificity (72 to 99%). False-positive reactions occur with some CoNS strains (S. haemolyticus and S. hominis) possessing type 8 capsular polysaccharide or a cell wall hemagglutinin (S. saprophyticus).
For both approaches, more details are given in previous editions of thisManual.

sect2.title: Identification of Species by Susceptibility Tests and by Biochemical Procedures
sect2.para: Resistance to novobiocin is intrinsic toS. saprophyticus and some other CoNS species but is uncommon in clinically important CoNS species of the “S. epidermidis group” (Table 4). Resistance to polymyxin B is usually observed for isolates of S. aureus, S. chromogenes, S. epidermidis, S. hyicus, and S. pettenkoferi and, to a lesser extent, for some strains of S. lugdunensis. Also, some other species without clinical relevance exhibit polymyxin B resistance (see Table 4). For methodologic details, see previous editions of this Manual.

For speed, standardization, cost reduction, and convenience, the classical tests for fermentation, oxidation, degradation, and hydrolysis of various substrates (details are available inchapter 20 of this Manual) have been incorporated into commercial manual and automated biochemical test systems (see below, Table 4, and chapter 6). They are often complemented by simultaneously performed antimicrobial susceptibility testing using an expert system and an interface with laboratory informatics software. Results from conventional tests (see previous editions of this Manual) may be slightly different from those obtained with rapid biochemical test systems due to the use of alternative indicators. Commercial identification systems identify staphylococci (and some other aerobic Gram-positive cocci) of clinical importance with an accuracy of 70 to >90%. It should be noted that the descriptions of novel species are often based on very few or even single isolates and, thus, reported results for biochemical and other phenotypic tests may not necessarily represent the complete range of possible test results. For some systems, reliability depends on additional testing as suggested by the manufacturer. Uncommon strains or phenotypic variants (e.g., SCVs) may have altered patterns of biochemical reactions, requiring molecular testing for identification.

Most systems are fairly successful in differentiatingS. aureus, S. epidermidis, and S. saprophyticus, while the accurate identification of less common species is more variable. Systems may fail in distinguishing commonly encountered staphylococcal species, in particular if phenotypic variants or isolates recovered from livestock and food are tested. A verification of the identification result by a second, independent approach is recommended for isolates presumptively identified as S. aureus, particularly for oxacillin-resistant strains. Additional tests should be performed on clinically significant isolates with questionable identification results that impact patient management. More details for specific commercial identification systems are given in previous editions of this Manual.

sect2.title: Species Identification by Nucleic Acid-Based Approaches
sect2.para: Extraction of staphylococcal nucleic acids may be challenging due to the Gram-positive nature of staphylococci, which necessitates special conditions for lysis of the cell wall. For this purpose, lysostaphin, lysozyme, proteinase K, and achromopeptidase have been used.

PCR fingerprinting techniques based on DNA sequence polymorphisms may be used, and species-specific variable regions of universal genes or genes unique toS. aureus or other staphylococcal species may serve as targets for identification and differentiation of staphylococcal isolates. Assays based on the specific amplification of fragments of the universal 16S and 23S rRNA genes and of their spacer sequences have been published (191–193). Other universal DNA targets shown to be useful for identification of staphylococci include genes encoding the RNA polymerase B (rpoB), elongation factor (tuf), gyrase (gyrA), manganese-dependent superoxide dismutase (sodA), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (gap), cytochrome d ubiquinol oxidase subunit II (cydB), and a 60-kDa heat shock protein (HSP60, or GroE) (194–198).

WGS and sequencing of selected universal phylogenetic marker genes represent the ultimate approaches to identify known and not-yet-described staphylococcal species (199). For 16S rRNA gene sequencing, the regions between bp 70 to 300, 420 to 500, 1000 to 1050, and 1250 to1290 (corresponding to nucleotides of the E. coli 16S rRNA gene) are useful for determining sequence differences among the staphylococcal species. Of note, the newly described S. argenteus cannot be distinguished from S. aureus by the means of 16S rRNA gene sequencing, and S. schweitzeri exhibits only a 1-bp difference relative to S. aureus (Table 6) (11, 94). For differentiation of staphylococcal subspecies, sequencing of partial rpoB gene sequences is superior to partial 16S rRNA gene sequencing (197). The recognized limitations of currently available public sequence databases apply to sequencing of staphylococcal isolates too (191).

For single staphylococcal species, specific target genes have been evaluated. The most popular and well-studied target forS. aureus identification is the nuc gene, which encodes the thermostable nuclease (thermonuclease, or TNase) (200, 201). Both recently delimited species of the S. aureus complex show mismatches comparing the nuc sequences, in particular that of S. schweitzeri, with the description of a nucMgene (11, 124). Whereas S. argenteus isolates, despite some mismatches in the PCR primer annealing positions, are detectable by the nuc PCR approach reported by Brakstad et al. (200), the described primers fail to generate an amplification product in the case of S. schweitzeri (Table 6) (124). For the S. intermedius nuc gene, a specific PCR has been described (202). Further specific targets used for identification of S. aureus include the genes encoding extracellular adherence protein (Eap) (eap), clumping factor (clfA), coagulase (coa), manganese-dependent superoxide dismutase (sodM, absent in CoNS), and the factors essential for the expression of methicillin resistance (femA and femB) as well as (for MRSA only) the staphylococcal insertion element IS431 (203–207). Misidentification using the fem factors may occur due to fem-negative S. aureus strains and CoNS with a gene structurally related to femA.

Usually, multiplex PCR- or microarray-based procedures developed for DNA-based direct pathogen identification from whole blood and from positive blood culture bottles, respectively, compriseS. aureus-specific and, depending on the assay, CoNS-specific genes as well as methicillin resistance-encoding sequences as targets, in addition to other major pathogens (208–210). Integrated analytical cutoffs for CoNS, which have been introduced to avoid false-positive findings due to skin CoNS contamination in whole blood samples, may omit true bloodstream infections by CoNS, e.g., in hematological patients with neutropenia (211). The molecular syndromic panel tests for rapid pneumonia diagnostics include also S. aureus and methicillin resistance targets (212). Studies on the S. aureus/MRSA-specific performance of these tests are not available.

ForS. saprophyticus, the heat shock repressor-encoding gene hrcA has been introduced for specific detection of this species (213). Further species-specific targets have been described for S. epidermidis (atlE, encoding autolysin E), S. haemolyticus (mvaA, encoding HMG-CoA reductase), and S. hominis (gap, encoding glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase) (214).

For molecular identification ofS. aureus and some other staphylococcal species isolated from culture, commercial tests are available, in some instances combined with the detection of resistance genes. Some assays were designed to detect MSSA and MRSA directly from positive blood cultures. Other assays include detection of MSSA and MRSA and sometimes other staphylococcal species as part of a broader panel that identifies bacteria directly from positive blood culture bottles. DNA oligonucleotide microarrays aiming to target specifically relevant staphylococcal species plus major drug resistance genes and virulence-associated genes have been designed and successfully tested on clinical isolates, indicating their potential for array-based high-throughput screening (215, 216).

Genus-specific and species-specific probes for rapid detection of staphylococci by fluorescencein situ hybridization (FISH) in blood culture, cerebrospinal fluid, and tissue (e.g., heart valves) specimens have been developed (217–219), and qualitative nucleic acid hybridization assays targeting rRNA sequences based on peptide nucleic acid FISH are commercially available. These assays are intended for rapid identification of S. aureus and several CoNS species in a smear prepared from a positive blood culture and may be combined with FISH assays for MRSA detection (220).
Another microbial characterization system utilizes ribotype pattern analysis for the differentiation of staphylococcal species with patterns in its database.

sect2.title: Species Identification by Spectroscopic Approaches
sect2.para: In the past few years, MALDI-TOF MS based on commercially available mass spectrometers has become routinely used in identification of staphylococcal isolates from human specimens (221–225).

Most studies reported identification of staphylococci at the species level of >97%; however, identification rates of CoNS were in general lower (223, 226–228). In an investigation of a large collection of clinical, molecularly defined strains of S. aureus and CoNS, the MALDI-TOF MS approach was shown to be faster than and equivalent to the molecularly defined reference methods irrespective of the methicillin resistance of the included strains (224). Nevertheless, for non-human-associated and/or newly described staphylococcal species, expansion of the MALDI-TOF MS in vitro diagnostics (IVD) databases is needed.
