Variable or even low identification results have been reported, e.g., for S. arlettae, S. caprae, S. carnosus, S. chromogenes, S. cohnii, S. condimenti, S. equorum, S. nepalensis, S. saprophyticus, M. sciuri, and S. xylosus (198, 229, 230). Other staphylococcal species are still missing from the databases. In particular, for the differentiation of the S. aureus complex, if necessary, amended database entries are needed (Table 6) (11, 231). A reduction of the species-level cut point or the performance of a duplicate test may improve the species-level identification rates for CoNS (230, 232). The use of MALDI-TOF MS for rapid identification of bacteria from positively flagged blood cultures subsequent to very short-term incubation on solid medium allows very early and reliable species identification (233). The mean cultivation times to successful identification with ethanol-formic acid protein extraction were 2.1 and 3.9 hours for S. aureus and CoNS, respectively (234). The use of colonies grown on chromogenic media as tested for CHROMagar MRSA (CHROMagar, Paris, France) may result in lower scores than the use of those grown on nonselective media; however, scores were still adequate for identification (235).

There are few or incomplete data for MALDI-TOF MS identification of other catalase-positive cocci. Some micrococci andA. otitis are part of the MS databases. Of note, the content and quality of the database and the standardization of variable parameters, such as culture conditions and length of incubation, are crucial to achieve reproducible results.

Nondestructive techniques, such as Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy, are applicable as alternative methods for the rapid identification of staphylococci (236, 237). The FTIR approach also allows discrimination between the SCV and the normal S. aureus phenotype (238).

sect2.title: Diagnosis of Toxin-Mediated Staphylococcal Syndromes
sect2.para: The diagnoses of TSS and SSSS are based on clinical signs (supplemented by serologic tests) and the detection of toxin production by staphylococcal isolates (S. aureus but also rarely other species). While samples from the skin manifestations are mostly culture negative, isolates are usually recovered from the suspected site of infection. Blood cultures are positive in fewer than 5% of cases of staphylococcal TSS. In patients with TSS, protective antibodies against causative PTSAgs are absent or present at very low levels. However, seroconversion after onset of the disease and during convalescence may be observed. The same phenomenon holds true for exfoliatin antibodies in patients with SSSS. Currently available immunoassays for antibody detection are for research use only. Beyond the recognition of the characteristic rapid onset and the clinical signs, staphylococcal food poisoning is difficult to verify because the incriminated food source may not contain cultivable staphylococcal cells, and detection of staphylococcal enterotoxin is required.

Traditional immunological procedures may be used to measure the toxin in culture supernatants of isolated strains, in contaminated food extracts, or in patient specimens. Commercially available kits for the detection of strains producing TSST-1, staphylococcal enterotoxins, and exfoliative (epidermolytic) toxins A and B are offered; however, they are limited in availability and FDA-approved tests are not available. A quantitative real-time immuno-PCR was described for the detection of small amounts of enterotoxins (239). Since phenotypic methods may be hampered by low sensitivity and specificity (cross-reactivity between PTSAgs) and in vitro expression of PTSAgs might be negatively influenced by various factors, detection of PTSAg/ET-encoding sequences by nucleic acid-based methods has come into favor (240–243).

PCR procedures targeting the genes for the PVL and other leukocidal (synergohymenotropic) pore-forming toxins produced byS. aureus have been established (76). The detection of PVL-encoding genes from culture can be done separately by respective commercial assays (244). Several phenotypic assays for PVL toxin detection in S. aureus cultures have been developed, such as an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, an immunochromatographic membrane-based lateral-flow assay, and an immunochromatographic test (245, 246).

sect1.title: Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae
sect1.para: Micrococci and staphylococci might be easily confused with one another because of similar cellular morphologies, Gram stain appearances, and positive catalase activities. The exact species affiliation of micrococci may frequently be misjudged (247). The frequent pigmentation of micrococcal colonies with a high convex profile leads to their presumptive identification as members of the families Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae. Colonies of M. luteus, K. varians, and the kytococcal species are characterized by yellowish tints (Fig. 2). K. kristinae and D. nishinomiyaensis appear orange-like, and K. rosea shows pink to red colonies. Some species (e.g., M. lylae) or strains of the usually pigmented species are nonpigmented. On routine blood agar, R. mucilaginosa colonies are mucoid or sticky, transparent to white, and nonhemolytic and in the majority of cases adhere to the agar (differentiation from streptococci). This organism may be distinguished from other similar organisms by its weak catalase reaction and its inability to grow in the presence of 5% NaCl.

In the clinical laboratory, micrococcal species can be preliminarily distinguished from staphylococci by their resistance to furazolidone (100 μg/disk; resistance is indicated by a <9-mm zone diameter) and lysostaphin (20 μg/disk; resistance, no zone) and susceptibility to bacitracin (0.04 U/disk; susceptibility, ≥10-mm zone diameter), in contrast to members of the genusStaphylococcus, which show inverse susceptibility patterns (zone diameters as follows: furazolidone, ≥15 mm; lysostaphin, 10 to 16 mm; bacitracin, no zone). Details are available in Table 3 and previous editions of this Manual. In contrast to most staphylococci, micrococci are positive by the modified oxidase test. Regarded as a reference method to distinguish micrococcal species from staphylococci, the fermentation of glucose in a manner similar to that of the oxidation-fermentation test for nonfermenters requires a specific oxidation-fermentation medium and prolonged incubation. In contrast to staphylococci, micrococci are characterized by the lack of acid production from glucose under anaerobic conditions.

Key physiological features for differentiation of species are found inTable 4. Data concerning the applicability of manual and automated identification systems for members of Micrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae are given in the respective Staphylococcus sections; however, their use is limited to a small spectrum of the clinical micrococcal species. Several species reported to occur in human specimens, including those of the genera Dermacoccus, Micrococcus, Kocuria, Kytococcus, and Rothia, have been included in the MALDI-TOF MS IVD databases; however, systematic studies on their quality are lacking. In addition, entries for other members of the Micrococcales are found in the MALDI-TOF MS libraries (see respective IVD and research-use-only lists from Bruker and bioMérieux). In cases of doubt and extraordinary clinical relevance, the use of sequencing-based approaches is recommended for definite species recognition.

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Sections of Columbia blood agar plates after 48 h of incubation showing yellow colonies of M. luteus (A), cream-white colonies of M. lylae (B), pastel-pink colonies of K. rosea (C), and orange colonies of D. nishinomiyaensis (D).

sect1.title: Alloiococcus
sect1.para: The cultivation ofA. otitis from middle ear fluid is often challenging due to the need for extended incubation times and relatively small colonies. After 2 to 5 days of incubation with 5% CO2 on blood agar at 37°C, alloiococci form small alpha-hemolytic colonies (248). Colonies formed on brain heart infusion agar with 5% rabbit blood are small, moist, and slightly yellow at 72 h, and the blood is partially hemolyzed. Applying a higher CO2 environment (7.5%) and a slightly lower temperature (35°C) has been associated with rates of higher cultivation success (105). A. otitis can be distinguished from similar organisms by its positive catalase and negative oxidase activities, its obligate aerobic nature, and its inability to produce acid from glucose or other carbohydrates. Growth occurs in the presence of 6.5% NaCl and on bile esculin agar. No growth occurs at 10°C or 45°C. A. otitis is included in the database of the API Strep gallery (bioMérieux). This species is part of the MALDI-TOF MS IVD libraries (Bruker and bioMérieux).

As the bacterium is quite inert biochemically, molecular methods are often necessary to confirm the identification. For the molecular verification of suspected colonies, anA. otitis-specific PCR assay has been described (249). A PCR assay for direct detection of this microorganism in clinical specimens has been reported as part of a multiplex approach targeting pathogens that cause otitis media with effusion (250).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Modern typing approaches for staphylococci based on phenotype structures include the MALDI-TOF MS and whole-cell fingerprinting techniques (e.g., FTIR spectroscopy), while traditional phenotyping techniques, such as phage typing, capsule serotyping, antibiotic susceptibility pattern analysis, and other biotyping methods, have been replaced by sequence-based typing methods. SmaI macrorestriction pattern analysis by PFGE was the acknowledged gold standard tool for decades, both for outbreak investigations and for classification schemata (251). However, PFGE has been largely abandoned due to its low throughput, limited portability, and problems with nomenclature and intercenter reproducibility. Of note, ST398 S. aureus isolates are refractory to SmaI restriction.

MLST remains the primary reference method for defining the core genetic population structure ofS. aureus complex (252, 253). In a standardized manner, the allelic polymorphisms of seven housekeeping genes are indexed. MLST ST assignment can also be made from whole-genome sequence data using any of a number of bioinformatics applications. A web-based database is available (https://pubmlst.org/organisms/staphylococcus-aureus). However, MLST has limited discriminatory power and a low-throughput capacity in the context of MRSA outbreak investigations and S. aureus surveillance in general. In the case of common ancestry but assumed distinct epidemiological origins of MRSA isolates, subtyping of SCCmec or the presence or absence of toxin genes may provide additional information (e.g., the USA300 clone frequently belongs to ST8, and carries SCCmec type IVa and the PVL genes) (http://www.sccmec.org/) (254). One advantage of MLST is that closely related STs (differing by one or two alleles) can be combined into “clonal clusters” (CCs), a useful classification scheme for large-scale epidemiologic studies. Phylogenies defined by S. aureus MLST types map closely to phylogenic population structures determined by core genome sequence data, and thus MLST classification alone is useful in defining the broad genomic relatedness among a collection of strains.

spa typing, based on the number of polymorphisms and the sequence of tandem repeat elements of the hypervariable X region of the S. aureus protein A (spa) gene, is the basis of a single-locus sequence typing approach that has become one of the primary genotyping methods for MRSA surveillance (255, 256). Clonal clusters of closely related spa types have been defined, although these are used less commonly than MLST-CCs. Besides excellent reproducibility, other advantages include low costs, high throughput, a standardized nomenclature, and complete portability of data transferable into an international database (https://spa.ridom.de/) curated by SeqNet.org (http://www.seqnet.org/). Like MLST, spa typing has limited discriminatory power because certain spa types are common in a given geographic region. For particular genetic lineages, misclassification may occur, necessitating the use of additional tests for reliable inference. In various instances, individual spa types have been identified in two or more strains with distantly related MLSTs. Another limitation is that S. aureus isolates with a small number of tandem repeat elements in the X region of the spa gene are regarded as being untypeable. spa typing is also applicable for the other members of the S. aureus complex.

Other molecular typing techniques also applied to the typing of staphylococci include several band-based molecular-fingerprinting approaches, ribotyping, multiple-locus variable-number tandem-repeat analysis, and microarray-based approaches. These are limited either by high cost or low throughput capacity or by limited ability to discriminate closely related strains.

Recently, WGS has begun to replace traditional molecular typing methods, serving as a universal approach that may provide information useful for outbreak investigation, surveillance purposes, detection of unknown and/or emerging strains, and prediction of the clinical importance of a given isolate (257–259). However, costs (although rapidly declining), the complexity of bioinformatics processing, lack of a universal nomenclature, challenging interpretation of sequence data, and, with one exception (EpiSeq, bioMérieux), the lack of a commercial analysis software pipeline still hamper its use for routine purposes.

While many typing systems have been developed and evaluated forS. aureus, fewer applications are available for CoNS and other coagulase-positive staphylococci. These include antibiotic resistance analysis, phage typing, slime production testing, and genotyping procedures (WGS, PFGE, and ribotyping). There are also established MLST classification schemes for S. chromogenes, S. epidermidis, S. haemolyticus, S. hominis, S. lugdunensis, and S. pseudintermedius (260–264).

For micrococcal species, phage typing and PFGE approaches applying phage sets and restriction enzymes, respectively, different from those used for staphylococci have been described. PFGE and restriction fragment length polymorphism approaches have been reported forAlloiococcus.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Because serological testing for antistaphylococcal antibodies lacks specificity and predictive accuracy, it plays no role in the diagnosis of most staphylococcal diseases. The one exception is the determination of protective antibodies in the case of toxin-mediated syndromes such as TSS and SSSS (see above). For the other microorganisms discussed in this chapter, detection of antibodies is not clinically useful.

sect2.title: Genetic Basis and Prevalence of Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect2.para: The genetic mechanisms of resistance to the different antibiotics are manifold, but basically the same within theStaphylococcus genus, which can lead to diagnostic problems, in particular for the unambiguous distinction of MRSA from MR-CoNS. A number of studies and reviews describing the antimicrobial and biocide susceptibilities of clinically important staphylococcal species have been published (44, 265–267). Networks that provide online or published resistance data for staphylococci have also been established. These include the National Healthcare Safety Network (http://www.cdc.gov/hai/), the European Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (https://ecdc.europa.eu/en/about-us/partnerships-and-networks/disease-and-laboratory-networks/ears-net), the Asian Network for Surveillance of Resistant Pathogens (http://www.ansorp.org/), and the International Nosocomial Infection Control Consortium (https://inicc.org).

InS. aureus and human-adapted CoNS isolates recovered from clinical specimens, penicillin resistance is common (e.g., approximately 75 to 80% in S. aureus and S. epidermidis). Methicillin resistance mediated by the mecA gene or its homologs is the most important resistance mechanism, as it has a profound impact on patient management by excluding all traditional β-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, group 1 to 4 cephalosporins, and carbapenems) from the antibiotic armamentarium.

The most important mechanism causing β-lactam resistance in staphylococcal and macrococcal species is the acquisition of themecA gene or its homologs. They encode an additional penicillin-binding protein (PBP), designated PBP2a (mecA encoded) or PBP2c (mecC encoded), responsible for the reduced activities of traditional β-lactam antibiotics. For staphylococci, the PBP-encoding gene and its regulators are part of the SCCmec, a foreign, mobile DNA element (268), which may originate from M. sciuri and related species and/or M. caseolyticus (269–271). Recently, plasmid-encoded mecB-mediated resistance, formerly known only to occur in macrococci (15), was detected in S. aureus (272). Homologs of the mecA gene have been described, comprising mecA1 and mecA2; mecB; mecC, mecC1, mecC2, and mecC3; and mecD (hitherto only in M. caseolyticus) (273, 274). For the designation of novel mecA gene homologs, a guideline exists (275). mecC possession (276, 277) results in the expression of a functional PBP2a homolog, likewise leading to methicillin resistance, although the affinity for oxacillin is higher than for cefoxitin, which has consequences for susceptibility testing (see below) (276, 278). Fourteen major variants of SCCmec, types I to XIV, and many subtypes have been recognized (276, 277, 279–288). SCCmec types I, II, III, IV, VI, and VIII are predominantly associated with HA-MRSA strains, and IVa, V, and VII are reported for CA-MRSA strains. mecA-based LA-MRSA strains are mainly limited to SCCmec types IV and V; types IX, X, and XII are rarely reported (54). mecC-associated LA-MRSA is characterized by the possession of the SCCmec XI element.

Resistance to ceftobiprole and ceftaroline, newer cephalosporins with MRSA activity (also referred to as “5th-generation cephalosporins”), has been increasingly reported. This resistance type is most often based on PBP2 missense mutations, and the resistance rates range between 0.3% and 33.5% among MRSA isolates worldwide (289–294).

Multidrug resistance is regularly observed in HA-MRSA strains and often includes resistance to aminoglycosides, fosfomycin, fusidic acid, ketolides, lincosamides, macrolides, quinolones, rifampin, tetracyclines, and/or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (295, 296). S. aureus isolates resistant to newer agents, such as daptomycin, tigecycline, omadacycline, and members of the oxazolidinones (linezolid and tedizolid), have been noted, including plasmid-mediated resistance to linezolid based on the acquisition of the cfr and optrA genes (265, 297–302). The transferable multiresistance gene cfr encoding a 23S rRNA-modifying methyltransferase confers resistance not only to linezolid but also to streptogramin A, lincosamides, phenicols, and pleuromutilins. The ABC transporter-encoding optrA gene causes resistance to phenicols in addition to oxazolidinones, including tedizolid (303, 304).

Compared to HA-MRSA, CA- and LA-MRSA strains are still more frequently susceptible to non-β-lactam antibiotic classes; however, the differences in the resistance profiles are dwindling (305, 306). Almost all LA-MRSA CC398 isolates exhibit tetracycline resistance (307).

Vancomycin-intermediateS. aureus (VISA) isolates (MIC of 4 to 8 μg/ml) (308) and their putative precursors, termed heterogeneous VISA (hVISA) strains, were identified first in Japan in 1996 (309) and subsequently in the United States and other regions. The mechanism of resistance for hVISA and VISA strains is not due to a single gene but is complex and can be obtained by several pathways, all of which, however, include cell wall alterations resulting in reorganization and thickening in addition to reduced autolytic activity (310). Since most VISA strains are also resistant to teicoplanin, the acronym “GISA” (glycopeptide-intermediate S. aureus) is preferred by some. A few clinical isolates that are resistant to teicoplanin but fully susceptible to vancomycin have been reported (311). Recently, a VISA strain was reported that tested nonsusceptible to dalbavancin, a long-acting lipoglycopeptide (312). Also, heteroresistance or tolerance to daptomycin has been detected in hVISA and VISA isolates (313, 314).

To date, all vancomycin-resistantS. aureus (VRSA) have been MRSA possessing the vanA gene cluster, which is transferred from vancomycin-resistant enterococci. In 2002, the first vancomycin-resistant S. aureus (VRSA) strains were reported in the United States (315). Outside the United States, VRSA has been reported mainly from India, Iran, and Pakistan, and single cases are known from Portugal and Brazil. However, VRSA are still seldom identified, probably due to reduction in fitness (316). The MICs for S. aureus isolates currently defined as vancomycin resistant according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) (M100-S31) are ≥16 μg/ml (308).

For members of theS. intermedius group, widespread emergence of resistance to methicillin, in particular as methicillin-resistant S. pseudintermedius (MRSP), as well as to other antibiotics has been observed (317, 318).

More than 90% of all health care-associated CoNS (mainlyS. epidermidis and S. haemolyticus) are resistant to penicillin due to β-lactamase production, and resistance to methicillin and other agents can be as high as 60 to 80% for health care-associated isolates (296). Isolates with increased ceftobiprole and ceftaroline MICs have been reported (319). In terms of glycopeptides, resistant CoNS isolates have been described primarily as resistant to teicoplanin (320). However, the categorization as teicoplanin resistant largely depends on the breakpoints used (321). Overall, resistance of CoNS to oxazolidinones remains uncommon (300, 322, 323).

Intrinsic resistances should be considered, since all staphylococcal species are intrinsically resistant to ceftazidime, aztreonam, temocillin, polymyxin B/colistin, and nalidixic acid (324). Species-specific intrinsic resistances should be noted for fusidic acid (S. saprophyticus), fosfomycin (S. capitis and S. saprophyticus), and novobiocin (S. cohnii, S. xylosus, and S. saprophyticus) (324).

Beyond resistance to classical antibiotics, increasing resistance of staphylococci to biocides and antiseptics as well as to heavy metals and metalloids (zinc, copper, and arsenic) has to be noted (325, 326). Due to the routine use of copper and zinc as feed additives, heavy metal resistance is particularly prevalent in MRSA and MR-CoNS from livestock, potentially facilitating coselection of antibiotic resistance (327, 328).

sect2.title: Determination of Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect2.para: Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of staphylococci may be performed conventionally according to the latest versions of the respective Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) or European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) reference method documents (308, 329) or by commercial systems as described in chapters 73 to 76 of this Manual. Differences between CLSI and EUCAST breakpoints (formerly “interpretative criteria”) have to be taken into account. Direct detection of MRSA is discussed in “Direct Examination” above. For SCVs, no approved method has been developed to determine susceptibility.

Special attention should be taken when phenotypic testing is performed in the following situations: (i) detection of penicillinase production, (ii) detection of methicillin resistance, (iii) testing of reduced susceptibility to vancomycin, (iv) susceptibility testing of lincosamide (inducible clindamycin resistance), and (v) susceptibility testing of daptomycin.

Correct determination of penicillin susceptibility is pivotal for the clinician’s decision to use penicillin for treatment ofS. aureus infections. Both CLSI and EUCAST warn that false-susceptible results can be seen using both the MIC breakpoint for susceptibility of ≤0.125 mg/liter or the zone diameter breakpoint for susceptibility of ≥29 mm (10-unit disks) or ≥26 mm (1-unit disks). They recommend testing for β-lactamase production either by disk diffusion (penicillin zone-edge test), distinguishing between sharp (i.e., β-lactamase-positive) and fuzzy (i.e., β-lactamase-negative) zone edges, or by PCR to detect the encoding blaZ gene (308, 329, 330). It should be noted that nitrocefin-based assays do not have the necessary sensitivity to be used as confirmatory tests and that chromogenic cephalosporin-based tests do not reliably detect penicillinase (329, 330). For non-S. aureus isolates, phenotypic tests are not reliable.

Strains that are oxacillin (cefoxitin) resistant, i.e., MRSA, should be considered resistant to all β-lactams, including penicillins, carbapenems, and cephalosporins (except for the cephalosporins with anti-MRSA activity). Detection of methicillin resistance represents the most important task in determining the antimicrobial susceptibilities of staphylococci, in particular to identify MRSA with high accuracy. Of note, traditional methods have reduced sensitivity and specificity in distinguishing methicillin-resistant from methicillin-susceptible isolates due to heteroresistance and, forS. aureus, the occurrence of borderline oxacillin-resistant S. aureus (BORSA) strains characterized by β-lactamase hyperproduction (331). With the enhanced discriminatory power of applying cefoxitin instead of oxacillin as the agent for detecting methicillin resistance (both mecA and mecC mediated), most of these problems have disappeared. The use of cefoxitin obviates the need for specific assay conditions (see previous editions of this Manual). In contrast, oxacillin MIC determination continues to require the addition of 2% NaCl to the medium, a maximum incubation temperature of 35°C, and a full 24 h of incubation. Even when these optimal expression conditions are present, MICs below the breakpoint, indicating false susceptibility, can still be obtained for some mecA- and especially for mecC-positive isolates. This phenomenon is due to heterogeneous PBP2a expression of some MRSA isolates, where only a small fraction of the bacterial cell population (10−8 to 10−4) expresses the resistance phenotype under in vitro test conditions (332). The resistant subpopulation may thus be overlooked because it usually grows more slowly than the susceptible population. In addition, truly oxacillin-susceptible mecA-positive S. aureus isolates were described in a few cases as a result of mutations of the accessory FemXAB proteins or due to lack of the derepression of the mecA gene (333, 334).

In the context of MRSA diagnostics, screening approaches must be distinguished from methods for definitive determination of methicillin resistance. For culture-based MRSA screening to detect colonization (preferentially nasal, but also pharyngeal or rectal), selective agar media (e.g., mannitol salt agar) supplemented with oxacillin or, preferably, cefoxitin were widely used in the past (335). Cefoxitin-based agar media containing chromogenic enzyme substrates have largely replaced them due to their better sensitivity and specificity. They are also suitable for mecC-MRSA (336, 337). Nevertheless, confirmation of species identification is recommended for some of them. In general, the exact observance of minimum cultivation time is decisive for the sensitivity of MRSA detection by chromogenic media, in particular for those with reduced incubation times. Inclusion of a broth enrichment step prior to plating enhances sensitivity but delays results. A commercial MRSA screening broth is also on the market. For molecular MRSA screening, please refer to the section “Direct Examination.”

The use of cefoxitin for MIC determination as well as in disk diffusion (30-μg disks) is currently the method preferred by both CLSI and EUCAST (http://www.eucast.org) for the detection of methicillin resistance in S. aureus, S. lugdunensis, and CoNS; for the latest breakpoints, refer to the current versions of the respective CLSI and EUCAST documents (308, 329). Since the cefoxitin screen, whether performed by MIC or disk tests, is less predictive for methicillin resistance in S. pseudintermedius and S. schleiferi than in other staphylococci, oxacillin disks (1 μg) are recommended, indicating mecA-based methicillin resistance (308, 329, 338, 339).

According to CLSI, oxacillin may also be used for MIC testing to detect methicillin resistance in staphylococci with separate breakpoints forS. aureus and S. lugdunensis (oxacillin, MIC ≥4 μg/ml; resistance to cefoxitin, MIC ≥8 μg/ml) (308). For staphylococcal isolates other than S. aureus and S. lugdunensis, the presence of mecA is predicted by applying lower oxacillin MIC breakpoints (resistance to oxacillin, MIC ≥1.0 μg/ml) (308). EUCAST notes that S. aureus and S. lugdunensis isolates with cefoxitin MICs of >4 μg/ml and S. saprophyticus isolates with cefoxitin MICs of >8 μg/ml are methicillin resistant (and those with oxacillin MICs of >2 μg/ml are mostly methicillin resistant, respectively); however, for other staphylococcal species, the cefoxitin MIC was found to be a poorer predictor of methicillin resistance than the disk diffusion test (329). The low growth rate of SCVs prevents the use of disk diffusion and automated methods to determine the susceptibilities of these strains (111, 340, 341).

An alternative method for the detection of methicillin resistance is the use of anti-PBP2a monoclonal antibodies available in a latex agglutination assay or immunochromatographic assay that may be performed on isolated colonies from a pure culture. These assays, however, do not, at least not with certainty, detectmecC or mecB isolates due to only 63% identity of the amino acid composition of PBP2a and “PBP2c” (342). Prior cefoxitin induction may lead to overcoming the low affinity of the monoclonal anti-PBP2a antibodies to “PBP2c” as shown for an immunochromatographic assay, but at the cost of speed and convenience (342). If the latex test is used for SCVs, then the number of colonies must be increased 100-fold (340).

For definite verification of a given MRSA isolate, the occurrence of both a methicillin resistance-determining gene and a molecularS. aureus species-specific marker (see above) has to be proven, representing the gold standard. In particular, for heterogeneous methicillin-resistant staphylococci, strains displaying growth-impaired phenotypes (SCVs), or S. aureus strains with borderline oxacillin resistance, the methicillin resistance of cultivated staphylococcal isolates should be confirmed by detection of the mecA gene (343), which is by far the most common of the mec gene family. At least in the case of unexplainable discrepancies between a positive MRSA result obtained by culture-based approaches and a negative result obtained by molecular approaches targeting mecA and/or the SCCmec-orfX junction, testing of mecA homologs should be included. The same holds true for CoNS if molecular verification of oxacillin resistance is desired. The use of pure colony material is a vital premise for this approach. For the detection of mecC, mecB, and other mec alleles, specific oligonucleotide primers and probes have been described and are used in diverse in-house and commercially available amplification- and microarray-based approaches (179, 180, 215, 272, 276, 344, 345). In rare cases, amino acid substitutions present in the endogenous PBPs 1, 2, and 3 may also lead to the MRSA phenotype (346).

Testing staphylococci for reduced sensitivity to glycopeptides including lipoglycopeptides is still challenging. Disk diffusion is unable to discriminate susceptible isolates from hVISA and VISA isolates and, thus, is not recommended for glycopeptide susceptibility testing by both CLSI and EUCAST. Susceptibility testing ofS. aureus and CoNS for glycopeptides should be performed by applying MIC methods only, and the assays should be read after a full 24 h of incubation.

The different underlying mechanisms leading to vancomycin nonsusceptibility are not addressed by EUCAST cutoffs (329). CLSI has kept an intermediate category to differentiate from the vanA-positive VRSA strains (308). Irrespective of the criteria used, staphylococcal isolates with vancomycin MIC of 4 μg/ml and above should be considered fully resistant from a treatment perspective.

According to CLSI guidelines, VRSA strains (MIC ≥16 μg/ml) are reliably detected by the broth microdilution reference method (for screening, the MIC is ≥8 μg/ml), most FDA-cleared automated systems, and a brain heart infusion (BHI) vancomycin (6 μg/ml) agar screen plate (309). Detection of the VISA phenotype is unreliable and underreported by routine susceptibility testing methods, including the BHI vancomycin agar dilution and automated methods (347). According to CLSI recommendations, S. aureus isolates for which vancomycin MICs are 4 to 8 μg/ml are classified as VISA (308). For other staphylococcal species, isolates with vancomycin MICs of 8 to 16 μg/ml should be considered as intermediate and ≥32 μg/ml as resistant (308). The CLSI recommends sending S. aureus and any other staphylococcal isolates for which the vancomycin MIC is ≥8 μg/ml and ≥32 μg/ml to a referral laboratory for confirmation (308).

The glycopeptide MIC breakpoints have been considerably lowered by EUCAST (resistance to vancomycin and teicoplanin, >2 μg/ml forS. aureus and >4 μg/ml for CoNS) to avoid reporting of VISA/GISA isolates as “intermediate” and to address the finding that strains of the hVISA and VISA phenotypes appear to be associated with impaired clinical responses to vancomycin (329, 348). While there is agreement of poor clinical outcome of treatment by vancomycin in infections due to S. aureus isolates with vancomycin MICs of >2 μg/ml, it is still a matter of debate whether isolates with vancomycin MICs of >1.0 are also associated with impaired clinical outcome. It seems that there is no evidence of the so-called “vancomycin MIC creep” phenomenon in general, but it may occur as a local problem (349).

Detection of hVISA requires a modified population analysis profile–area under the curve method (350). As this method is laborious, complicated, and not suited for routine use, a number of screening assays including antibiotic-incorporated agar media and specialized gradient tests (macroEtest) have been developed (310, 351).
For the other (lipo)glycopeptides, deviating MIC breakpoints or the lack of MIC breakpoints must be taken into account (308, 329).

Inducible clindamycin resistance can be detected only when the drug is tested in combination with a macrolide, either as a combination well using broth microdilution methods or by placing the two disks adjacent to each other when performing disk diffusion; for details, see the CLSI and EUCAST documents (308, 329).

Daptomycin can be tested only using MIC methods and requires an adjustment of the broth medium such that it contains a final concentration of 50 μg/ml calcium (308, 329). The results of daptomycin susceptibility testing should not be reported in the case of isolates from the respiratory tract (308).
For fosfomycin testing, agar dilution is the reference method and MICs must be determined in the presence of glucose-6-phophate (25 μg/ml) (329).

Additional information on the determination of antimicrobial susceptibilities is contained inchapters 73 to 76 of this Manual. There are no particular CLSI and EUCAST methods for susceptibility testing of micrococci and alloiococci. For the recently segregated staphylococcal species (Mammaliicoccus spp.) there are no special recommendations; thus, respective recommendations for non-S. aureus species should continue to be used until different recommendations are made, if necessary.

Provided that the underlying genetic mechanisms are known and are genetically determinable, specific DNA amplification methods or WGS could be used for the detection of resistance-encoding genes, respective single-nucleotide variants, and transposon-mediated resistance in staphylococci. With a concordance of 98.6% with phenotypic testing by standardized EUCAST disk diffusion method, WGS was shown to predictin silico antibiotic resistance profiles for S. aureus (258).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Distinguishing contaminants and colonizers from staphylococcal and micrococcal isolates causing infection continues to be an important challenge for laboratorians and clinicians. It is imperative to have an appreciation of the quality of the specimen under consideration. Clinical features and the results of other investigations should be taken into account during the interpretative process. There is no replacement for good communication between laboratory staff and treating clinicians.

Cultivation of the causative pathogen and identification to the species level, complemented byin vitro susceptibility testing, represent the gold standard for the diagnosis of staphylococcal infections. The most critical step during interpretation of a culture that is suspect for staphylococci is to distinguish between S. aureus and other species. Due to the importance of a report of “S. aureus” and, in particular, of “MRSA” for prognosis, therapy, hospital hygiene, and infection control, any uncertainty regarding the species identification or the susceptibility to oxacillin and/or cefoxitin should be investigated via a second independent method. Considering costs and rapidity, applicable routine protocols may comprise the use of chromogenic media for MRSA screening, MALDI-TOF MS, automated systems, and latex agglutination assays for identification and/or susceptibility testing. When the identification is in doubt, further tests, preferably nucleic acid-based approaches, should be applied. However, the need for additional procedures must be weighed against delays in informing the treating clinician concerning a preliminary S. aureus identification as the putative causative agent.

To avoid misinterpretation of their clinical significance, as well as for infection prevention and control measures, reporting ofS. argenteus and S. schweitzeri—if they are specifically distinguished from S. aureus—should include an amendment stating that these species are part of the S. aureus complex (94). In the case of the detection of methicillin resistance in both species, the recommendation is to proceed as recommended for MRSA unless future studies would indicate another course of action.

Species-level identification of CoNS associated with infection (in particular if they are deep tissue and bloodstream related), especially in the case of a pure culture, is current standard laboratory practice, whereas contaminants and colonizing CoNS do not require identification and susceptibility testing. In particular, in the case ofS. lugdunensis, species identification is mandatory for interpretation of the results of susceptibility testing. The same holds true for the non-S. aureus coagulase-positive species S. pseudintermedius and S. coagulans, which are often misidentified as CoNS due to negative results of latex agglutination assays. To rule out S. saprophyticus for urine isolates, the novobiocin test may be used. Other CoNS have also been increasingly described as causative pathogens of severe infections. Several reports suggest that cultures of colonially indistinguishable CoNS may contain multiple different strains (352). Extending the incubation period of the initial cultures to 72 h may enable different colony types to be more readily identified but also delays the time to the final culture result.

Unless there is strong evidence to the contrary, isolation ofS. aureus from a sterile-site culture (such as aspirated pus, blood, or cerebrospinal fluid) should be considered clinically significant. Contamination of high-quality samples by S. aureus is rare, and further samples should be obtained if there is clinical doubt. Interpreting the isolation of S. aureus from specimens contaminated with elements of a normal microbiota requires consideration of setting, clinical features, and recent interventions. Quantitative culture may be helpful, for example, for interpretation of a bronchoalveolar lavage or urine sample. In patients with S. aureus endocarditis, bacteremia is often continuous and associated with higher loads, while in cases with transient bacteremia (e.g., manipulations with mucous membrane trauma), bacteremia is associated with lower loads and typically has a short duration. Because quantitative blood cultures are not routinely performed, the time between incubation onset and growth detection (defined as the time to positivity) may provide additional information in continuous blood culture monitoring systems. Rapid growth of S. aureus (within 14 h after the initiation of incubation) has been associated with a high likelihood of endovascular infection, delayed clearance, and complications (353). Isolation of S. aureus from surgical wounds and other sites, such as ulcers, may represent infection or colonization, and the clinician’s response to the culture report should be guided by a bedside assessment of signs and symptoms of infection. Colonization alone is an insufficient reason to treat, unless the patient is colonized by MRSA and decolonization is undertaken as part of a specific infection control policy.

Interpreting the significance of cultures that are positive for CoNS is more challenging than forS. aureus. CoNS are an important cause of health care-associated bloodstream infections, but they are also the most common contaminants of blood cultures (354). Blood samples or biopsy specimens taken without careful skin cleaning and disinfection will become contaminated with the microbiota of the skin or mucous membranes. However, even careful attention to collection techniques will not prevent all episodes of contamination. Interpretation of blood cultures positive for CoNS requires knowledge of the presence of prosthetic material in the intravascular compartment, risk factors for true CoNS sepsis, such as prematurity or the presence of an impaired immune system, and clinical features of sepsis. Factors helpful in distinguishing between true-positive cultures with clinical impact and therapeutic consequences and contaminated specimens taken from a patient with clinical features of infection include (i) isolation of a strain in pure culture from the infected site or body fluid and (ii) the repeated isolation of the same strain or combination of strains over the course of the infection (355). An algorithm to reduce misclassification of health care-associated bloodstream infections due to CoNS includes requirements for at least two blood cultures positive for the same species of CoNS within 5 days or one positive blood culture plus clinical evidence of infection (356).

The presence of the same CoNS strain on an intravenous catheter tip and in a blood culture is supportive evidence for intravenous catheter-associated bacteremia. Measurement of differential times to positivity between blood cultures drawn through the central venous catheter and those drawn from the peripheral vein was reported as highly sensitive and specific for thein situ diagnosis of catheter-related bloodstream infection in patients with short- and long-term catheters; however, other studies did not show that this method was of major diagnostic value (357, 358). Isolation of CoNS from peritoneal dialysis fluid or cerebrospinal fluid taken from ventricular shunts in a patient suspected of having infection is usually significant. While most contaminated clinical specimens produce mixed cultures of different strains and/or species, some infections may be attributable to more than one strain or species (352).

For patients with complicated cases who probably have a true CoNS infection, it is advisable to develop a sampling strategy. This is particularly pertinent for patients with low-grade infection associated with implanted prosthetic material, such as from a joint replacement or vascular graft. Samples should include those from each anatomical layer or region, and fresh instruments should be used to gather deep-site samples (359).

Susceptibility testing, and in particular the detection of methicillin resistance, should always be carried out following the identification ofS. aureus and S. pseudintermedius. For surveillance cultures to detect MRSA colonization, susceptibility testing beyond the determination of methicillin resistance may be needed only for patients undergoing decolonization to predict the success of mupirocin or other decolonization therapy. In this case, testing for high-level mupirocin resistance may be recommended. All CoNS associated with true infection require susceptibility testing.

The considerations of clinical significance discussed for CoNS are also appropriate for members of the familiesMicrococcaceae and Dermacoccaceae; however, the criteria used for distinguishing etiologically relevant isolates from contaminants and colonizers should be applied much more strictly. Since species of the genus Kytococcus are resistant to some β-lactams, they should be (if clinically relevant) carefully distinguished from other micrococci that are usually susceptible.
